headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Raytheon Q4 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Mark, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Raytheon Q4 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Mark, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Todd Ernst, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today on our fourth quarter conference call. The result that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we'll reference are available on our website at rathe
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today on our fourth quarter conference call. The result that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we'll reference are available on our website at ratheon.com. 
Following this morning's call, an archive of both the audio replay and a printable version of the slides will be available in the Investor Relations section of our website. With me today are Tom Kennedy, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Toby O'Brien, our Chief Financial Officer. We'll start with some brief remarks by Tom and Toby, and then we'll move on to questions. 
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I'd like to caution you regarding our forward-looking statements. Any matters discussed today that are not historical facts, particularly comments regarding the company's future plans, objectives and expected performance constitute forward-looking statements. These statements are based on a wide range of assumptions that the company believes are reasonable, but are subject to a range of uncertainties and risks that are summarized at the end of our earnings release and are discussed in detail in our SEC filings. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Todd. Good morning, everyone. I am very pleased with both our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results and I'd like to begin with touching on a few highlights. Our total book-to-bill ratio for the year was $1.09 million. This reflects strong
componenttext:
Thank you, Todd. Good morning, everyone. I am very pleased with both our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results and I'd like to begin with touching on a few highlights. 
Our total book-to-bill ratio for the year was $1.09 million. This reflects strong global demand for our Advanced Solutions and positions us well going into 2016. We finished the full year with top line growth of 2%, driven by our growth in our international business, which more than offset a slight decline in domestic. Company segment margins in 2015 were as expected at 13.1% as the team delivered solid operating performance. 
Cash flow was also solid, providing us the opportunity to return the majority of our cash flow to shareholders, while also funding our pension plans and invest in our future growth. So all in all, the company's performing very well and we are confident in our future. As you can see from our 2015 results and the 2016 outlook, the global threat environment continues to drive demand for Raytheon solutions. I would also add that in my conversation with our global customers, it is clear that short-term shifts and economic growth factors have taken a backseat to ensuring the sovereignty and security of the nations that face these security threats. In particular, let me highlight what we are seeing in 3 regions. 
In the Middle East, demands singles increased last year despite the decline in oil prices. Tensions within the region are driving demand for missile-defense, long-range radars, modernized command and control systems, sensors, cybersecurity and precision munitions, areas that are aligned with our core strengths. I've been asked many times how oil price have impacted demand. From our viewpoint, we have not seen a negative impact and here is one o  many examples why. 
Over the past year alone, Patriot has intercepted more than a dozen ballistic missiles fired in the region, missiles that otherwise could have caused significant casualties and damage to critical infrastructure and defense sites. In the Asia-Pacific region, customers are also updating their missile-defense systems, sensors and other capabilities in light of recent developments there. Increased tensions related to territorial disputes and evolving economic interests are motivating allies in this region to invest more heavily in deterrent capabilities to protect our national interests. As you may recall, South Korea awarded us a significant upgrade to its Patriot systems in 2015. 
Looking forward in 2016, we see opportunities across the region in tactical radars, ship based radars, missiles, force protection systems and precision munitions. And in Europe, we are seeing renewed and increased interest from a number of countries and acquiring integrated air and missile defense solutions, providing additional opportunities for Patriot and NASAMs. Domestically, we are pleased to see the passage of the Bipartisan Budget Act, which adjusted the defense budget caps higher for fiscal year '16 and fiscal year '17, including a 15% increase in modernization funding in fiscal year '16. These changes provided much-needed funding for our armed forces while also improving visibility and predictability for the defense industry. This will yield a positive impact on our results beginning in 2016 and then continuing into 2017. 
The units reemerged from several years of declining U.S. Defense budgets are now beginning to see growth, the environment remains competitive. To ensure Raytheon's long-term competitive advantage, we have increased our independent research and development, capital expenditures and other investments to fund the development of advanced game changing apologies from the future, ranging from hypersonics and cybersecurity to directed energy. 
As expected, IR&D reached 3% of our sales in 2015, a similar level as expected in 2016. And let me give you some more details about our 2015 results. Strong demand from global customers drove bookings of $25.2 billion for the full year, a 5% increase over 2014. Domestic bookings were strong with a full-year book-to-bill ratio of 1.04. This sets up a better than originally expected domestic revenue growth outlook for 2016, which I'll discuss more in a moment. 
International comprised 34% of our total bookings in 2015 and our international book-to-bill ratio was a very robust 1.19 for the year. Total backlog at the end of 2015 was $34.7 billion, an increase of $1.1 billion dollars over 2014, again providing a solid foundation as we move into 2016. International ended the year at 43% of total backlog compared to 40% at year end 2014. Successful execution of our growth strategy and increasing demand from our global customers resulted in return to growth in 2015, a year earlier than we had originally expected. 
Our full-year 2015 international sales increased 9% over 2014, reaching 31% of our total annual sales, a new company record. In addition, for the second consecutive year, we saw good growth in classified sales, which increased about 6% in the year. In this environment, we are also continuously looking for more ways to lower our cost, enhance our competitiveness and improve affordability for our customers. A few examples include executing our strategic sourcing strategy to reduce cost in our supply chain, leveraging our centralized global business services organization to more efficiently provide back office support for the businesses and reducing our footprint, taking out a gross total of 1.9 million square feet in 2015. 
In addition, we have kicked off a new complexity reduction initiative to reduce costs and simplify business processes across the company. 
Looking forward to 2016, we expect to see continued strong demand that should ultimately drive our bookings to the $25 billion to $26 billion range for the year. This would translate into a book-to-bill ratio of roughly 1.05. Key bookings for the year include Qatar early warning radar, the AMD phase of the next-generation jammer and SM-3. More than ever before, demand from our global customers is broad-based and diversified. Along with these strong bookings we experienced in 2015, this continues strength should position us well to deliver revenue growth of between 3% to 5% in 2016, which is better than what we had mentioned when we provided our initial outlook during the Q3 earnings call. 
I would add that this includes an expectation of 2% to 4% growth from domestic customers. This would be the first time we've seen growth in our domestic business since 2009. Further, cash flow from operations is expected to increase significantly in 2016 from solid 2015 levels. The strong fundamental performance provides the foundation for the continuation of our balanced capital deployment strategy, with the objective of creating shareholder value. Our #1 priority from his executive our growth strategy and investing in our sales. Beyond this, we remain committed to providing a competitive dividend. We also continue to see value on our stock and expect to continue to share buyback at the 2015's robust levels. 
Part of our growth strategy is bring our advanced cybersecurity capabilities to government and commercial customers around the world. In 2015, in support of this strategy, we increased our presence in the commercial cybersecurity market in a meaningful way with the formation of Raytheon|Websense. And earlier this month, we changed this name to Force Point to more effectively brand and position our broad cybersecurity capabilities in the market. We further strengthened Forcepoint by completing the acquisition of Stone Soft after the close of the fourth quarter. The small acquisition, which is consistent with our M&A strategy that we've articulated over the past several calls, provides next generation firewall technology that fills an important technology gap and broadens our cybersecurity capabilities. The Stone Soft acquisition will become part of the Forcepoint business segment. We're excited about the breadth and depth of the product offerings at Forcepoint that place us in a strong competitive position. 
I like to close by thanking the Raytheon team for a great year and for the dedication and all the efforts that went into returning the company to growth ahead of schedule, while continuing to deliver for our global customers. 
With that, let me turn it over to Toby.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Tom. I have a few opening remarks starting with the fourth quarter and full-year results, then I'll discuss our outlook for 2016. After that, we'll open up the call for questions. During my remarks, I will be referring to the web slides that
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Tom. I have a few opening remarks starting with the fourth quarter and full-year results, then I'll discuss our outlook for 2016. After that, we'll open up the call for questions. During my remarks, I will be referring to the web slides that we issued earlier this morning, which are posted on our website. Okay. Would everyone please move to Page 3. 
We are pleased with the solid performance the team delivered in both the fourth quarter and the full year with bookings, sales, EPS and operating cash flow all consistent with or better than our expectations. We had strong bookings in the fourth quarter at $7.9 billion, resulting in a book-to-bill ratio of 1.24. And for the year, we had bookings of $25.2 billion, resulting in a book-to-bill ratio of 1.09. This sets the stage for continued growth in 2016, which I'll discuss in more detail in just a few minutes. 
Sales were $6.3 billion in the quarter, up 3%, led by our missiles, IDS and Forcepoint businesses. International sales grew 16% in the fourth quarter. And for the year, sales were up 2% ending at $23.2 billion. Our EPS from continuing operations was $1.85 for the quarter and $6.75 for the full year, which I will give a little more color on in a few minutes. We also generated strong operating cash flow of $813 million for the quarter and $2.3 billion for the year after a $200 million pretax discretionary pension contribution, which was not in our prior guidance. 
Additionally, during the quarter, the company repurchased 2 million shares of common stock for $250 million, bringing the full year 2015 repurchases to 9 million shares for about $1 billion. As we have previously disclosed in the fourth quarter of 2015, our Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of up to an additional $2 billion of the company's outstanding common stock. The company ended the year with a solid balance sheet and net debt of approximately $2.1 billion. 
Turning now to Page 4. Let me go through some of the details of our fourth quarter and full-year results. As I've mentioned earlier, we had strong bookings of $7.9 billion in the quarter and $25.2 billion for the full year, resulting in a year end backlog of $34.7 billion. The company ended 2015 with the funded backlog of $25.1 billion, an increase of $2 billion from year-end 2014. It's worth noting that both IDS and Missile Systems had outstanding bookings performance for the full-year 2015. For the quarter, international orders represented 27% of our total company bookings and for the full year was 34% of full-year bookings. And as Tom mentioned earlier, at the end of 2015, approximately 43% of our total backlog was international. 
Turning now to Page 5. We had fourth quarter sales of $6.3 billion, up 3% over the same period in 2014. This was at the high end of the guidance range we had set in October. So looking now at the businesses. 
IDS had net sales of $1.7 billion in the quarter and they were up 5% from the same period last year, primarily due to higher sales on certain international Patriot programs and on the Air Warfare Destroyer program. Net sales at IIS were $1.4 billion in the quarter, down from the same period last year, primarily due to lower sales on an international classified program. Missile Systems had fourth quarter 2015 net sales of $1.9 billion, up 9% compared to the fourth quarter of 2014. The increase was primarily due to higher sales on Paveway. SAS had net sales of $1.6 billion in Q4, the change was spread across numerous programs with no one significant driver. And for Forcepoint, the increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Websense, which we completed in the second quarter of 2015.  As a reminder, fourth quarter 2014 included the results for Raytheon Cyber Products only. 
For the full year, sales were $23.2 billion, up approximately 2% over full-year 2014, consistent with expectations. International sales growth more than offset a slight decline in domestic sales. 
Moving ahead to Page 6. We delivered solid operational performance in quarter and the full year. Looking at business margins in the quarter. As expected in the fourth quarter of 2015, IDS received a contract modification to restructure the AWD program, essentially separating our incentive fees from the shipyard's performance. This resulted in a favorable $53 million adjustment in the fourth quarter of 2015 for IDS. Missile Systems and SAS margins both exceeded the guidance range that we provided back in October, while both IIS and Forcepoint met our guidance. 
Turning to Page 7. We had solid operating margin performance for the year. Segment margins were 13.1%, which was consistent with our expectations. And as a reminder, this included $181 million for the eBorder settlement earlier in the year at IIS, worth about 80 basis points. 
On Page 8, you'll see both the fourth quarter and full-year EPS. In the fourth quarter 2015, our EPS was $1.85 and for the full year was $6.75. EPS for the quarter was strong and above the guidance we provided you in October even after accounting for the extension of the R&D tax credit. As a reminder, the R&D tax credit was worth about $0.11 and was not in our prior guidance. 
Moving on to our 2016 guidance on Page 9. We see sales in the range of between $24 billion and $24.5 billion, up 3% to 5% from 2015. The increase is driven by growth in both our domestic and international business. Our 2016 outlook for the deferred revenue adjustment is $67 million and for the amortization of acquired intangibles is $121 million. It's important to note that effective January 1, 2016, we reclassified amortization of acquired intangibles and the deferred revenue adjustment. This change affects all businesses other than Forcepoint, which has already been reporting that way. These noncash items will no longer be reported within the business segments, instead this will be reported in separate deferred revenue adjustments and amortization of acquired intangibles lines that we have provided for you here. A reconciliation that walks you from the prior method to the current one is in Attachment G the press release. 
As for pension, we see that 2016 FAS/CAS adjustment at a positive $428 million, which I'll discuss in just a minute. We expect net interest expense to be between $220 million and $230 million. We see our average diluted shares outstanding to be between $296 million and $298 million on a full-year basis, a reduction of approximately 2% to 3%, driven by the continuation of our share repurchase program, which we expect at levels comparable to 2015. 
We expect our effective tax rate to be approximately 30%. Our 2016 tax rate is higher than 2015, primarily due to the $0.29 per share favorable tax settlement we received in 2015. It's important to note that our 2016 tax rate includes the R&D tax credit, which was permanently extended at the end of 2015. In 2016, we see our EPS to be in the range of $6.80 to $7. Our operating cash flow for continuing operations for 2016 is expected to be between $2.7 billion and $3 billion compared to $2.3 billion in 2015. As we sit here today, we do not anticipate making a discretionary contribution to our pension plans in 2016. As we previously mentioned, we did make a $200 million discretionary contribution in 2015. 
Before moving on to Page 10, I want to mention that we expect our 2016 bookings to be between $25 billion and $26 billion, driven by demand from a broad base of domestic and international customers. And we expect stronger bookings in the second half of the year similar to the last several years. 
Continuing on to Page 10. Before I cover the 2016 guidance by business, it's important to note that effective January 1, 2016, we reorganized the IDS and IIS business segments to move certain air traffic systems, border and critical infrastructure protection and highway tolling programs from IDS to IIS. We did this to more efficiently leverage our capabilities within the businesses. To assist you with your modeling, you'll find the recast segment data in the attachments provided at the end of the earnings release. 
Now moving to our initial 2016 guidance by business. At the midpoint of the sales range, we expect to see growth in all of our businesses in 2016. With respect to segment margins, consistent with our prior comments, we expect 2016 margins to continue to be solid in the 12.4% to 12.6% range, which is in line to slightly up when you compare to 2015 excluding the eBorders settlement. And similar to 2015, our 2016 segment margin outlook assumes that IR&D is approximately 3% of sales. 
I would also like to point out that when it makes sense, we have and will continue to make opportunistic investments in specific next-generation U.S. programs to better position the company for a longer-term organic growth, investments which we believe will create value for our shareholders. At IDS, we see margins in the 15.9% to 16.1% range. I want to point out that our full-year 2016 guidance includes positive operating income at IDS related to an expected exit from certain business ventures later in 2016, which you can think of in the $100 million to $125 million range. Excluding this, the change from 2015 is driven by mix, most notably, we are continuing to ramp up on several new programs, including on a couple of Patriot awards that we received in early 2015 from South Korea and Saudi Arabia. As you know, we typically see lower margins with the inception of longer duration programs, which can increase overtime as we retire risk and drive operational efficiencies. 
We expect IIS margins of 7.4% to 7.6%. This is in line year-over-year when you adjust for the 2015 eBorders settlement. We see missiles margins in the 13% to 13.2% range, consistent with 2015. SAS margins are expected to be in a 12.9% to 13.1% range, down from 2015, driven by mix as a result of completing some international programs as well as from higher business investments in 2016. And at Forcepoint, we expect margins to be in the 11.5% to 12.5% range. This includes the impact from the Stone Soft acquisition that Tom discussed earlier. Without this impact, margins would have be approximately 15%. 
If you now turn to Page 11. We've provided you with our 2016 outlook by quarter. You'll notice that sales ramped up throughout the year. And on Page 12, as we have done in the past, we've provided the summary of the financial impact from pensions in 2015 as well as the projected impact for 2016 through 2018, holding all assumptions constant. As I've mentioned earlier, we see the FAS/CAS adjustment in 2016 at a positive $428 million, which reflects our investment returns in 2015 on our U.S. pension assets, which were flat in the December 31 discount rate of 4.5%. The discount rate is up 40 basis points from last year. 
Looking beyond 2016, keep in mind, each 25 basis point change in the discount rate drives a $70 million to $80 change in FAS/CAS. And finally, on Page 13, we have provided an updated 3-year outlook of the acquisition accounting adjustments to help you with your long-term modeling. Please note that you'll see a significant decline in the deferred revenue adjustment over the period and the amortization of acquired intangible assets will begin to decline more significantly after 2018. 
Before concluding, as we have discussed on past earnings calls with regard to our capital deployment strategy, we expect to continue to generate strong free cash flow and maintain a strong balance sheet at our current credit rating going forward. We remain focused on deploying capital to create value for our shareholders and customers. This includes internal investments to support our growth plans as well as returning capital to shareholders through share buybacks and dividends, making smaller targeted acquisitions that fit our technology and global growth needs and, from time to time, making discretionary contributions to our pension plans. 
Let me conclude by saying that in 2015, Raytheon again delivered solid operating performance with bookings, sales, earnings and operating cash flow all on or ahead of expectations. Book-to-bill was strong and our international business grew significantly. We have a strong balance sheet, which gives us flexibility and options to continue to drive shareholder value and we are well positioned to grow in 2016 and beyond, both in our international and domestic business. 
So with that, we'll open up the call for questions.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jason Gursky from Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Jason Gursky from Citi.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could just walk through the cadence for the year. A little bit more detail, perhaps we're talking a little bit about opportunities and risks to the cadence for the year. What would the cost to come in a little earlier. What would ca
componenttext: I was wondering if you could just walk through the cadence for the year. A little bit more detail, perhaps we're talking a little bit about opportunities and risks to the cadence for the year. What would the cost to come in a little earlier. What would cause things to get pushed out and just kind of how you generally view the risks and opportunities for the cadence of the year, that would be great.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Toby. So I think if we step back from this and look at a high level on the cadence, what you see from the revenue profile is not too dramatically different than last year. It's influenced by -- as you would expect, the timing for awards, especially i
componenttext: It's Toby. So I think if we step back from this and look at a high level on the cadence, what you see from the revenue profile is not too dramatically different than last year. It's influenced by -- as you would expect, the timing for awards, especially in 2015, and we had a strong back half to the year. So we see an influence to the ramp up in the second half of the year, in part driven by the growth and the timing of the awards we saw in late '15. That flows through, obviously, to the EPS cadence. And the other thing I would add, the exit of business ventures at IDS that I talked about, that's planned to be in the second half in Q3, which has an influence on the back half cadence from an EPS point of view as well.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Toby, are you willing to offer a little bit more granularity on the businesses that you're exiting?
componenttext: Toby, are you willing to offer a little bit more granularity on the businesses that you're exiting?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I'd put it this way. We constantly look at our portfolio. We talked on the call here about a couple of things. One, which is just moving up some of the businesses from IDS to IIS because we think it's been a rep somewhat efficiencies given how tho
componenttext: I think I'd put it this way. We constantly look at our portfolio. We talked on the call here about a couple of things. One, which is just moving up some of the businesses from IDS to IIS because we think it's been a rep somewhat efficiencies given how those products have been matured. They're more of a service support model, where in the past IIS had actually performed a lot of work on it. So we think we'll get more efficiencies out of that. I can't get into too much detail right now beyond what I said for the exit of the business ventures at IDS just because of the confidentiality around it. But we certainly can talk more about that once that is concluded, as we said here, we expect by the third quarter.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Doug Harned from Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Doug Harned from Bernstein.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm interested in IDS because if we go back a year ago, when you were looking forward, you were expecting some margin expansion that you would see operating margins up in the 15% range. And it seemed as the year went on, you looked at new awards coming in
componenttext: I'm interested in IDS because if we go back a year ago, when you were looking forward, you were expecting some margin expansion that you would see operating margins up in the 15% range. And it seemed as the year went on, you looked at new awards coming in, that pushed out in time, that margin expansion. But now as you look at 2016 and if you make adjustments for the exit from these businesses, it seems like you're still at a lower margin level than one might think -- one might have expected. Could you talk about how you look at that IDS trajectory now? I know you've met a couple of the new programs which you may put some pressure on margins in the near term. But I'm trying to understand, when can we expect to get kind of the full margin advantage one might expect from a mature set of international programs.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Doug. Let me kind of walk through that and try to give some more color around that. So as I've mentioned and you alluded to, we do have $100 million to $125 million in the 2016 forecast for IDS related to the exit of a business venture. I will note,
componenttext: Sure, Doug. Let me kind of walk through that and try to give some more color around that. So as I've mentioned and you alluded to, we do have $100 million to $125 million in the 2016 forecast for IDS related to the exit of a business venture. I will note, at IDS in any given year, in part because of the nature of their programs and the size of them, we have had favorable profit adjustments that were significant, maybe about half of the size of this, if you look back over time. So this pickup is a bit larger, but it does help to offset in '16 some of the mix that we've been talking about that you just referred to with the ramp up of these programs that are in the early stages. Further, as we've talked about at both IDS and across the company, we are investing more, particularly in strategic areas where we do see significant growth opportunities. We also continue to execute on some lower margin programs at IDS such as AMDR, the Qatar 8, a classified radar program that we won last year and all this taken together is a key component of our growth story, but in the near term, it is impacting our IDS margins as well. At the end of the day, even with the IDS margin, we have been able to maintain a solid company margin position and deliver top line growth due to the strength of the portfolio. And we continue to be focused on driving down our costs, overhead and other costs, for the last several years. And as you know, we've seen significant improvements from a number of different initiatives there around facilities reductions, factory automation, strategic sourcing, expanding our shared services, working on our organization structure when we've collapsed from 6 to 4 businesses and, as we've talked about, internationally, we changed our model on how we approach to international business. And that is clearly paying off from a growth perspective overall and internationally. As we now are resuming growth, we'll continue to drive cost down with our objective to improve and grow earnings to both top line and margin improvement. As far as the cadence of IDS margin going forward, I would think of it this way. As you said, if you were to adjust for the exit of the business venture, I think as we said in the past, we would expect year-over-year to continue to see IDS margins improve incrementally. Again, adjusting for the impact of the business venture as these larger production programs that run 5 years kind of get into the sweet spot into '17 and '18, which would drive that improved margin at IDS.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I have it right, then you're saying that you still expect with this attractive international contracts that you can get up to the margins, the high 16s maybe margins we've seen in the past. But if this has just taken longer than you probably would h
componenttext: So if I have it right, then you're saying that you still expect with this attractive international contracts that you can get up to the margins, the high 16s maybe margins we've seen in the past. But if this has just taken longer than you probably would have expected 6 to 12 months ago.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd put it -- so I'm not to give you beyond what we put out there for '16 margin expectation for IDS other than directional indication or cadence. But yes, we really haven't changed our thinking around this. You got to keep in mind, as we said, in t
componenttext: Well, I'd put it -- so I'm not to give you beyond what we put out there for '16 margin expectation for IDS other than directional indication or cadence. But yes, we really haven't changed our thinking around this. You got to keep in mind, as we said, in the case of Patriot, these awards generally run 5 years. And these are -- we're only 1 year into those, right? And it's usually in the plus or minus the third year of those programs, which will be starting in '17 when we normally see the opportunity to retire risk, drive efficiencies. We also had, if you recall, at the end of '14, a major award for Qatar. Again, that will kind be hitting the sweet spot when we get into '17. So I won't put a specific margin bogey out there, but we definitely would see improvement in '17 and improvement over that into '18 driven by these large programs.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro from Shapiro Research.

And then you have a bigger increase in 2016 that was some of that something was missed in '15 or can you just explain kind of the walk from the '15 number, say, 2 5 to get to the 2 7 to 3?

componenttextpreview: Yes. So the way to think of it, George, you're right. We came in towards the low end when you adjust for the discretionary contribution. When you look at the change year-over-year, it's primarily driven by a combination of our net pension funding and lowe
componenttext: Yes. So the way to think of it, George, you're right. We came in towards the low end when you adjust for the discretionary contribution. When you look at the change year-over-year, it's primarily driven by a combination of our net pension funding and lower cash taxes. From an operational or a program level, we still -- we see things kind of in line with the cadence that we saw in 2015.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then one quick one. What was the organic growth if we looked at Forcepoint and put in the acquisition, so what would it have been year-over-year?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the company?
componenttext: For the company?

componenttextpreview: For Forcepoint. Yes, I mean, if we put in the acquisition you made, we put in Websense last year.

componenttext: Yes, sure. So for 2015, for Forcepoint normalized on a full-year basis, the revenue growth would've been flat. That would have been higher sales of the new products that the TRITON platform offset by a decline in the legacy products on the web filtering, which is consistent with what we have been expecting. If you roll it forward to 2016 and exclude the acquisition that Tom talked about for the next-gen firewall, we'd be looking at high single-digit growth on a normalized basis.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, you mentioned you're getting quite a few questions about the potential impact of the oil price on your defense export sales. I was wondering if you could size the proportion of either your backlog or your sales that are going into the Middle East and
componenttext: Tom, you mentioned you're getting quite a few questions about the potential impact of the oil price on your defense export sales. I was wondering if you could size the proportion of either your backlog or your sales that are going into the Middle East and whether you have seen any signs from those customers of any change in priorities or deferrals of orders or deliveries or anything in particular. And then secondly, do you think this is the peak as a percentage of exports in your backlog?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent question. #1 is I just did get back from the Middle East, visiting our key customers in multiple countries. And so my statement in the script was really based on the communications that I had directly with the leaders of these countries. And wha
componenttext: Excellent question. #1 is I just did get back from the Middle East, visiting our key customers in multiple countries. And so my statement in the script was really based on the communications that I had directly with the leaders of these countries. And what I'm seeing, at least what I'm hearing from these leaders, is their #1 priority is to protect the sovereignty other nation. And the words they used, I mentioned this before and I heard it again just to say several weeks ago, is that a strong defense is a strong deterrence. And in fact, during my trip, we uncovered or told about several other opportunities in the region. So if anything, we're seeing a stronger demand than a slow down. And that's why my words were not seeing impact relative to the price of oil at this time. I hope that gives you a complete answer, but that's what I'm seeing directly from the leaders of these countries.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow-up on the backlog percentage. Do you think this is about as high as you're going to get with 43%?
componenttext: And just a follow-up on the backlog percentage. Do you think this is about as high as you're going to get with 43%?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not based on the opportunities we see out there. There's always opportunity to grow. It's just a matter of bringing those opportunities across the goal line.
componenttext: Not based on the opportunities we see out there. There's always opportunity to grow. It's just a matter of bringing those opportunities across the goal line.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to add a little bit on that. I mean, just to put a little context. We expect strong bookings to continue internationally to continue into 2016, roughly 35% plus or minus of the bookings that we -- that the range we gave you we expect to be inte
componenttext: Maybe just to add a little bit on that. I mean, just to put a little context. We expect strong bookings to continue internationally to continue into 2016, roughly 35% plus or minus of the bookings that we -- that the range we gave you we expect to be international. Keep in mind, we're projecting 2% to 4% growth domestically as a subset of the 3% to 5% at the company level. And we expect international sales to be roughly the same level in '16 as '15. So we continue to see, as Tom said, momentum in that area.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Sam Pearlstein from Wells Fargo.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk just philosophically about the decision you made to pull the amortization of intangibles and deferred revenue out of this segment. So I'm just wondering, when it comes to acquisition opportunities, doesn't that make the s
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk just philosophically about the decision you made to pull the amortization of intangibles and deferred revenue out of this segment. So I'm just wondering, when it comes to acquisition opportunities, doesn't that make the segments in a way willing to pay a little higher price than they would have otherwise. How do you make sure that now you've got the pricing right in the hurdle rates?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll give you the answer or my view here in 2 parts, right? So first of all, why we did it. So if you recall back April, May of last year when we announced the Websense deal. For that acquisition, we started with that convention but only limited t
componenttext: Yes. So I'll give you the answer or my view here in 2 parts, right? So first of all, why we did it. So if you recall back April, May of last year when we announced the Websense deal. For that acquisition, we started with that convention but only limited to that acquisition. And at the time, we contemplated doing it completely across the portfolio, but we didn't want to mess with the pure nature of the numbers around Websense. So we purposely deferred that to the end of the year to have kind of a clean break on into '16 and then obviously puts both of those elements on the same basis consistently across the company. So that's part of what why we did it. As far as the second part of your question, are we concerned about the businesses wanting or being willing to pay more. So even if work that were to be the case, we've done a pretty disciplined process here the company. We've got a core team and acquisition review team that all acquisitions have to go through. I'm on that. Tom's on that, as you would imagine, a few others. And through that, we've spent a lot of time around valuation looking at it 2, 3 different ways. And I won't get into any stats, but I would tell you, there are plenty of deals in the past that we lost because we wouldn't bid higher, right? We lost on price for lack of a better way to say it. So I think we got that right controls and process in place within the company to make sure that we continue to only bid and pay what is a fair value for any property.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up. The decisions and acquisitions are done at the corporate level, not at the business level.
componenttext: Just to follow up. The decisions and acquisitions are done at the corporate level, not at the business level.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: And if I can just follow up, Toby, if I look at the first quarter, you get the most working days but clearly, the lowest earnings. And I know you mentioned one of it was from the exit of those businesses later in the year. But how was it that earnings are so low that early in the year?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're right. There are more days, calendar days, in Q1. That said, we still show growth in Q1 on a year-over-year basis. I think as you know, in any given quarter, some of our revenue depends upon not just the number of days, but the timing of material w
componenttext: You're right. There are more days, calendar days, in Q1. That said, we still show growth in Q1 on a year-over-year basis. I think as you know, in any given quarter, some of our revenue depends upon not just the number of days, but the timing of material which is a significant portion of our cost base. We are guiding to 3% to 4% growth over last year's first quarter. And that puts our 2015 sales per day roughly in line for the quarter. So we don't see anything abnormal about it and part of it, again, I think, back to Jason's comment around the cadence with the strong bookings we saw in the second half of the year, especially domestically, we'd see more of a ramp on that towards the back half of the year on our programs.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to talk maybe philosophically for a second also. I think I heard you or Tom say that you're willing to make some strategic investments in programs. And if I look at one of your competitors which reported they acknowledged taking a charge in LRDR. A
componenttext: I want to talk maybe philosophically for a second also. I think I heard you or Tom say that you're willing to make some strategic investments in programs. And if I look at one of your competitors which reported they acknowledged taking a charge in LRDR. And I also -- I'm aware that you've been challenged a little bit in a classified program at IIS. So could you talk a little bit about what you're doing in terms of balancing growth opportunities versus making sure you build a, call it a wall of strategic advantage in your businesses, Tom?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think #1 is we do invest inside the company relative to ensuring that we have the right discriminators and differentiators to compete across all our businesses and not only just to compete, but obviously to win. And so those investments come thr
componenttext: Yes. So I think #1 is we do invest inside the company relative to ensuring that we have the right discriminators and differentiators to compete across all our businesses and not only just to compete, but obviously to win. And so those investments come through the avenue of IRAD, some capital investments, also people bringing on the right talent so that we can go and win those major competitions. Because we are the future franchises for the company. And that's been our overall strategy over the years. We look at programs that are going to have runs for decades. What's the next Patriot, one of the examples as air missile defense radar. That's going to be our next major franchise coming to fruition here in the next several years, next generation jammer win, the Fat D win. These are all franchise programs and we made sure over the years, that we have been investing in the right IRAD, in the right capital to support those projects. And then also in having the right talent on board. And that's something that we do as part of the company moving forward. Now the good news is we're seeing the results of those investments. And the results for these franchises that we won over the last couple of years and that we intend to continue to win as we move forward. And we see a lot of opportunity here in 2016, 2017 and 2018 already in terms of new franchise opportunities. And so Howard, I think the bottom line is, we're making the right investments and we're seeing the right results relative to these new franchises.

componenttext: I'm not seeing it any different than the past. What I'm seeing, which is nice, is I'm seeing more opportunities in the last couple of years than I saw in the prior years. So the bottom line is that there's a lot of opportunities out there and we, I would say, had a pretty good crystal ball in making sure we made the right investments to be prepared to win those opportunities.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a little bit of a follow-up, sort of contextually to Howard's question. But we saw the German obviously over Patriot last year. Sort of big the question about our expectations for Patriot over the next few years. And I was wondering if you could tal
componenttext: Maybe a little bit of a follow-up, sort of contextually to Howard's question. But we saw the German obviously over Patriot last year. Sort of big the question about our expectations for Patriot over the next few years. And I was wondering if you could talk about that maybe in the context of how much you've invested into things like facilities and R&D and headcount in anticipation of Patriot wins. And would it require you to maybe get a little bit more aggressive on price in the event that you sort of need the volume to cover some of those investments that you've made in anticipation of the awards on Patriot specifically?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on Patriot, the investments have come through contracts. And then the other capital business that we made or the normal investments we made to essentially be able to operate our factory and win in efficient manner. So that's -- I'll put that in co
componenttext: I think on Patriot, the investments have come through contracts. And then the other capital business that we made or the normal investments we made to essentially be able to operate our factory and win in efficient manner. So that's -- I'll put that in context. And let me put together the opportunities for Patriot and Context. There was just a recent announcement by the new minister of defense, in Poland relative to his support of pursuing the Patriot program with the U.S. government. In fact, he kind of did a joint announcement with the U.S. ambassador to Poland on that subject with an objective to be able to get something going here this year. So that's a really good news for us. That's a very large potential program for Poland there. And just as I've mentioned earlier, I just returned from the Middle East and their strong demand for additional Patriot assets there. I mentioned in my script a number of over 10 intercepts by Patriot against ballistic missiles just in that region of the Middle East. So there's a strong demand across Eastern Europe and also the Middle East for additional Patriot assets, but also for upgrade. For example, just in the upgrade area alone, there's an opportunity to upgrade 72 fire units just to configuration 3 plus. So there's upgrade potentials and then there's also the new potentials for countries like Poland and adding additional fire units to other countries in the Middle East region. And I'm sure you're reading the newspapers, like the information I'm getting, especially of all the Asia-Pacific activities are going on. In fact, today, there was an article relative to Fed and Korea where we also have just gotten an award on Patriot there, too. So the bottom line is there seems to be a significant demand out there across potable areas, Eastern Europe, Asia-Pacific region and the Middle East for missile defense and Patriot is the system that's proven and is the system of choice for the nations. That's what we're seeing.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I did mention. So that's part of the upgrade activities also. But there's definitely over a $5 billion just on upgrades to Configuration 3 plus. There's an opportunities on the radars that are in the billions of dollars there in terms of these AEs 36
componenttext: What I did mention. So that's part of the upgrade activities also. But there's definitely over a $5 billion just on upgrades to Configuration 3 plus. There's an opportunities on the radars that are in the billions of dollars there in terms of these AEs 360 radars. By the way, the was one of the request I had in several my meetings with key leaders in the Middle East, was a desire to have our new AEs at 360 added to their configurations. So I think that's getting out there, that capability is available and we are hearing getting demand signals from customers on that. So the bottom line is, as Patriot is a franchise and we continue to evolve it, we continue to upgrade it, increase its capabilities, add new technologies and we're seeing increased demand across those 3 major areas of the world. Again, the Eastern Europe, Asia-Pacific and also the Middle East.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tom, I think you guys said you expect international to be 35% of bookings in 2016. That would suggest that you really do about -- if you do the 25 5, you do about $9 billion up from what looks like 8 7. You have the Qatar award, but other than that, yo
componenttext: So Tom, I think you guys said you expect international to be 35% of bookings in 2016. That would suggest that you really do about -- if you do the 25 5, you do about $9 billion up from what looks like 8 7. You have the Qatar award, but other than that, you don't seem to have as many identified large individual awards as you did in 2015. Could you give us some more color of what would be driving that number that high?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you mentioned one of them, which is the Qatar EWR. We also have international Patriot greater than $1 billion worth of bookings that are in play. We have other activities in Qatar, which we're pursuing and we believe are accessible this year. There'
componenttext: Well, you mentioned one of them, which is the Qatar EWR. We also have international Patriot greater than $1 billion worth of bookings that are in play. We have other activities in Qatar, which we're pursuing and we believe are accessible this year. There's a whole FMS in the area Aegis of supporting Aegis Assure. And also, upgrades on some ships in the international marketplace. For those who don't know, we did at Aegis radar components and the sybsystems for that radar. That alone is, for example, over $300 million. And then in the whole area of missles, both air-to-air and air-to-surface missiles, a significant demand of greater than $3 billion across multiple missiles, so they're multiple contracts, there's no one contract in missiles that's going to do it, but that's our portfolio. We have a very diverse portfolio that allows us to add these systems up. International ISR was over $700 million. And then we have our normal airborne radars and ISR, systems that probably pretty close to $1 billion. So I think what's different this year than others is we're seeing demand signals across our whole portfolio on the international side. And why is that. Well, we mentioned before that we changed our strategy about 2 years ago. We went from a regional strategy to a country strategy. And in that country strategy, we focused not on the 1 or 2 customers we've had in the past 30 years, but we expanded that. Now we're seeing that, but these other customers are buying in the order of $500 million to $1 billion programs, not just a $2 billion program. So bottom line is our portfolio, which is diverse, is now diverse in the international marketplace and these opportunities are coming across in multiple across multiple of our products.

componenttext: So Tom, you've said that it takes 3 years to hit the margin sweet spot on 5-year Patriot contract. componenttext: It's Toby. I'll jump in on this one. I think you'd really want to think about that in '17. Okay. And other thing to keep in mind, with our missile program -- or international missile programs, they are essentially FMS and not direct commercial sales. So while they, relatively speaking, have some incremental margin compared to our domestic business, it is different than if it were a DCS type of sale.

So that's the flow-through, the start of the flow-through from a revenue point of view of the -- of what Tom just talk about from a demand perspective.
