componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen,, and welcome to the Raytheon Q1 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Mark, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Todd Ernst, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today on our First Quarter Conference Call. The results that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we reference are available on our website at raytheon
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today on our First Quarter Conference Call. The results that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we reference are available on our website at raytheon.com. Following this morning's call and archive of both the audio replay and a printable version of the slides will be available in the investors relations section of our website. With me today are Tom Kennedy, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Toby O'Brien, our Chief Financial Officer. We'll start with some brief remarks by Tom and Toby, and then we'll move on to questions. 
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I'd like to caution you regarding our forward-looking statements. Any matters discussed today that are not historical facts, particular comments regarding the company's future plans, objectives and expected performance, constitute forward-looking statements. These statements are based on a wide range of assumptions that the company believes are reasonable, but are subject to a range of uncertainties and risks that are summarized at the end of our next release and are discussed in detail in our SEC filings. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom,.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Todd. Good morning, everyone. Raytheon has had a good start out of the gates in 2016, so the company bookings reached 39% in the first quarter and book-to-bill ratio was 1.08, driven in part by a large year-over-year increase in demand in the M
componenttext:
Thank you, Todd. Good morning, everyone. Raytheon has had a good start out of the gates in 2016, so the company bookings reached 39% in the first quarter and book-to-bill ratio was 1.08, driven in part by a large year-over-year increase in demand in the Middle East, North Africa region as well as strong domestic bookings. Our first quarter sales were well above our expectations with strong growth at our Missile business. Cash flow and EPS were also better-than-expected. This good start gives us continued confidence in our full year outlook. 
Toby will cover the financial details with you in a few moments. Across our global markets, demand for precision unions, command-and-control including C5I solutions, force protection, integrated air and missile defense ISR platforms continues to be strong. As we've seen in prior quarters, our Middle East and North African customers are continuing to look past in term volatility in oil prices and are investing in high priority solutions to address an immediate and rapidly evolving threat environment. 
I visited the region earlier this month to celebrate our 50th anniversary in Saudi Arabia and met with customers. While there, I received firsthand feedback about the successful performance of our products and how they are helping protect citizens and critical infrastructure everyday. I can tell you from these discussions that the interest level across the entire region remains high for the types ofadvanced solutions we offer. One of the more significant upcoming opportunities includes an early warning radar system for Qatar at IDS, which we expect to be awarded later this year. This program, which will significantly increase the air and missile defense sensing capabilities for Qatar as a value approaching of $1 billion and has already been through the congressional notification process. As I mentioned earlier, our bookings in the quarter were strong. When looking across the businesses, at  key driver was space and airborne systems, which had a book-to-bill ratio of 1.7 in the quarter, driven by domestic space-based sensor solutions and both domestic and international classified. This was the second consecutive quarter of strong bookings at SAS. And building on this, after the close of the first quarter, we announced that SAS has received a $1 billion bookings  for the engineering and manufacturing development phase for the next-generation jammer franchise. These awards provide a solid foundation from which SAS will ramp sales growth into the second half of this year. In addition to SAS, we also saw a strong year-over-year increase in bookings in Missile systems, driven by a number of products including AMRAAM and SM-6. 
Before moving on, I would like to point out that our overall domestic classified business, which expressed a significant increase in full year 2015 bookings, continued to see strong demand into the first quarter of 2016. Book-to-bill for the total company domestic classified was 1.3 in the quarter. First quarter sales of the company increased 9% year-over-year. Our international revenue was up 17% and represented 30% of total sales. Domestic sales were up 6% with domestic classified sales increasing 12%. 
As I mentioned earlier, one of the key drivers of the company's first quarter sales was Missile Systems. Let me take a few moments to talk a little bit more about what is driving activity at Missiles. As many of you know, our Missile business includes a number of franchise programs. A global customers look to us to ensure that these programs continue to offer the most advanced capabilities, so that they can stay ahead of evolving threats. A great example of this in the quarter was solid growth from AMRAAM, where we are ramping up production on the latest most advanced version of the missile, 20D, while this missile shares the AMRAAM name with earlier versions and is vastly more capable across of our program portfolio and missiles, there are many other examples, where we create value by upgrading the systems technology including programs, such as the Missile, a premier ship missile for our global customers. Also, we are seeing opportunities to adapt the existing technology to new missions, such as in the case of SM-6 and Tom Hawk, which are now expanding into the anti-ship domain. 
Finally, we are developing new capabilities that are on the cutting edge of innovation, including hypersonics and directed energy. In addition to this, another growth driver of Missile Systems has been the increase in operating tempo of our U.S. interest of customers. As we sit here today, we see this continuing to be a revenue tailwind for the company at least through next year. The taking a step back, when you look at Raytheon over the past several quarters, it reinforces the value of our diverse portfolio of advanced solutions for our global customers. A recent book extent that SAS and Missile Systems, a significant bookings in longer cycle programs at IDS over the past couple of years as well as upcoming opportunities and the competitive position of IIS and Forcepoint and global cybersecurity marketsmore provide a strong foundation for future growth and margin expansion. 
We were encouraged by the U.S. fiscal year 2017 defense budget request in fight up request, which was released in February. The overall top line for the fiscal year '17 budget is consistent with the Bipartisan Budget Act 2015. With key electronic warfare, ISR, Missile defense, cyber and long-range strike, all areas that played to our strengths. And Department of Defense focused on high-end capabilities through its offset strategy elements aligns well with our high-end capabilities Raytheon is known for, and we are actively working with DoD in this area. We continue to see broad-based support for funding a robust national defense. 
Turning now to Forcepoint. We American's double progress to completing the integration of recent decorations recovery performance in the quarter was solid and above our expectation for the business remains on track to meet the growth objectives we outlined for you in prior calls as much as integration behind this. As today we announced the change in leadership at Forcepoint. Matthew was previously at Harbour Networks, will take over as Forcepoint CEO on May 9th. This change is designed to build on the growth capabilities of the integrated businesses. Matt has the background of managing technology companies and has a proven track record of driving growth. John McCormack who did an outstanding job managing Forcepoint, both when it was private and during the integration of with Raytheon staying on through the end of the year as an adviser. We thank john for all of his hard work and help is positioning Forcepoint to move to the next level. Forcepoint remains well positioned for the future. 
During the first quarter, we continue to execute our balanced capital deployment strategy. In March, we raised our dividend by 9.3%. This is the 12th consecutive annual increase will increase to our dividend, it reflects our view at a sustainable competitive dividend as a key capital deployment priority. 
We also repurchased $400 million of stock through our share repurchase program. And as we said on the call in January, we expect full year 2016 share buyback to approximately 2015 levels, market conditions permitting. 
Before concluding, I would like to touch on the topic that we don't often talk about on earnings calls, which is at most important to our shareholders, and that is corporate governance. The company is committed to being a leader in contemporary corporate governance, and we believe that good governance and as a shareholder value. In recent years, we have adopted a number of policies, processes and practices to ensure effective governments. To this end, in March, the Board of Directors voted to amend the company's bylaws to implement proxy access. Providing shareholders with the process by which they can include nominees and the company's annual meeting proxy materials. The implementation of proxy access follows on our previous adoption of shareholder action by written consent in 2014 and a special meeting measure in 2010. And further demonstrates Raytheon's commitments to world-class governance practices. 
In summary, we had a good order quarter with solid bookings, revenue growth and EPS performance. We continue to execute our growth strategies, while at the same time placing a high priority on driving shareholder value. So thank you to the entire run wanting for the good start of 2016. Together, we have built on the momentum generated by our 2015 return to growth by delivering a strong quarter for our company, customers and shareholders. With that, I'll turn it over to Toby.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom I have a few opening remarks starting with the first quarter highlights, and then we'll move on to questions. During my remarks, I will be referring to the website that we issued earlier this morning. If everyone to turn to Page 3. We are plea
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom I have a few opening remarks starting with the first quarter highlights, and then we'll move on to questions. During my remarks, I will be referring to the website that we issued earlier this morning. If everyone to turn to Page 3. We are pleased with the solid performance team delivered in the first quarter with bookings, sales, EPS and operating cash flow all better than our expectations. It's a good start for the year, and we're positioned well for achieving our full year outlook. 
We had solid bookings in the first quarter of $6.2 billion, resulting in an book-to-bill ratio of 1.08. Sales were $5.8 billion in the quarter, up 9% led by our Missile, SAS and Forcepoint businesses. Our EPS from continuing operations was $1.43, which I'll give a little more color on in just a moment. We generated strong operating cash flow of $325 million in the first quarter, primarily due to the timing of collections and tax payments. During the quarter, the company bought back 3.2 million shares of common stock under the share repurchase program for $400 million. And we announced last month that we increased our dividend by 9.3%, we have now raised our annual dividend every year for the past 20 years. I also want to point out that we raise in the EPS guidance that we provided in January. I'll discuss guidance further in just a few minutes. Turning now to Page 4. Let me start by providing some detail on our first quarter results. Companies bookings for the first quarter were $6.2 billion, an increase of approximately $1.7 billion over the same period last year. 
International awards represented 27% of the total bookings. And on a trailing 4-quarter basis, the book-to-bill ratio was 1.14. A few key bookings in the first quarter included $646 million on AMRAAM at Missiles, and at SAS, over $650 million on an international classified contract and the $553 million award on the Joint Polar Satellite System program. And shortly after the close of the quarter, The U.S. Navy awarded SAS of $1 billion contract of the next-generation jammer program for engineering and manufacturing development. Backlog at the end of the first quarter was $34.8 billion and on a funded basis was $26.2 billion, an increase of approximately $2.4 million in funded backlog compared to the first quarter of 2015. It's worth noting that we ended the first quarter of 2016 with approximately 42% of our backlog compressed of international programs. 
If you now move to Page 5. As I just mentioned, for the first quarter 2016, sales were higher than the guidance we set in January. Sales were particularly strong at both Missile and at SAS. We still expect sales for the company to ramp up throughout the year with the strong second half driven by our bookings over the past several quarters and the duration of our programs. 
Looking now at sales by business. IDS had first quarter 2016 net sales of $1.3 billion. The increase from Q1 2015 was primarily driven by higher sales on certain international Patriot programs. We expect IDS sales to increase as we move through the year as some of our international Patriot programs continue to ramp up. 
In the first quarter 2016, IIS had net sales of $1.5 billion. Compared with the same quarter last year, the increase is probably due to our cybersecurity and special mission programs. Missile Systems had first quarter 2016 net sales of $1.7 billion, a 17% increase from the first quarter 2015 was primarily due to both the Paveway and AMRAAM programs. SAS had net sales of $1.5 billion higher sales on classified programs, including an international program contributed to the 7% increase versus last year. And for Forcepoint, the increase is primarily due to the acquisitions of Websense, which we completed the second quarter of 2015 and Stonesoft stones of which was acquired in the first quarter of 2016.  As a reminder, first quarter 2015 included the results for only Raytheon Cyber Products. 
Moving ahead to Page 6. Let me spend a few minutes talking about our margins. Our operating margin was up 10.6% for the total company and 10.2% on a business segment basis. We did out 2 programs with some unique circumstances that impacted our margins in the quarter, one at IDS for $36 million, that's because it's in joint venture about half was offset through the noncontrolling interest line on the income statement. And one at Missiles for $22 million. We don't see any significant remaining financial exposure on these programs. If you exclude the 2 adjustments I just mentioned, our segment margins would be about 100 basis points higher than reported. 
In addition, as we talked about on last year's first quarter call, it's also important to note that in the first quarter of 2015, Missiles recorded a $25 million or approximately 170 basis points favorable resolution of a contractual issue related to a supplier settlement. As expected, IIS and SAS margins both were down compared to same period last year, primarily driven by a change in program mix. 
Also, IIS first quarter 2015 margin included the favorable eBorders settlement worth about 340 basis points or $0.42 per share on a total company basis. And at Forcepoint, the first quarter 2016 operating margin was slightly above our expectations for the quarter, driven by strong operating performance. We remain focused on margin improvement going forward and see our base -- business segments margin in the 12.4% to 12.6% range in the full year, consistent with the guidance we laid out in January. We also see our margin cadence improving as we move throughout the year. 
As we have discussed on past calls, we are continuously working for more ways to lower our cost, enhance our competitiveness and improve affordability for our customers. In a few examples include executing our strategic sourcing strategy to reduce cost in our supply chain, factory automation, complexity reduction initiatives and reducing our footprint. Given these efforts, our strong backlog and as we progress through the life cycle with some of our production programs, we continue to see opportunities for margin expansion. 
Turning now to Page 7. First quarter 2016 EPS of $1.43 was better-than-expected, driven largely by higher volume and the unrecognized tax benefit associated with the adoption of new accounting standard for stock compensation worth about $0.05. 
On Page 8, we are updating the company's financial outlook for 2016. We will still expect our full year 2016 net sales to be in the range of between $24 billion to $24.5 billion, up 3% to 5% from 2015. The increase is driven by growth in both our domestic and international business. We have increased the full year deferred revenue adjustment by $10 million to $77 million to reflect the updated estimate of purchasing accounting related to the Stonesoft acquisition we completed earlier in the year. We have lowered our effective tax rate to reflect the tax benefit associated with the adoption of new accounting standard for stock compensation that I just discussed, which in total is worth about $0.13 for the full year, with the additional $0.08 expected in the second quarter. We now expect our effective tax rate to be approximately 28.5%. And we have raised our full year 2016 EPS to reflect the tax benefit I just mentioned. We now expect our EPS to be in a range of between $6.93 and $7.13. 
As I discussed earlier, we repurchased 3.2 million in shares of common stock for $400 million in the quarter and continue to see our diluted share count in the range of between 296 million and 298 million shares for 2016, a 3% reduction at the midpoint of the range. 
Operating cash flow in the first quarter was strong. And we continue to see our full year 2016 operating cash flow outlook between $2.7 billion and $3 billion. And as you can see on Page 9, we've included guidance by business, which is unchanged from our prior outlook. I want to reiterate that at IDS, we still see margins in the 15.9% to 16.1% range. As I said, on the general recall, our full year 2016 guidance includes positive operating income at IDS related to an expected exit from certain business ventures later in 2016, which you cna now think of in the $125 million to $150 million range. This is subject to the finalization of the transaction, which we expect to close in the second half of the year. 
And as a reminder, when thinking about our 2017 company margin, we see opportunities for upside from 2016 levels, excluding the impact of this gain at IDS that I just discussed, which is expected to be worth about 50 to 60 basis points at the company level in 2016. 
Before moving on to Page 10, as I mentioned on the January call, we still see our 2016 bookings to be between $25 billion and $26 billion, driven by demand from the broad base of domestic and international customers. The first quarter was a good step to meeting this target. 
On Page 10, we provided some directional guidance on how we currently see the quarterly cadence for sales, EPS and operating cash flow for the balance of 2016. Here you can see the ramp up we have been referring to in the second half of the year. I want to point out that we now expect the second quarter sales to be in the range of just under $5.7 billion to $5.8 billion, lower than our prior guidance due to the timing of volume that occurred in Q1 that I talked about earlier. And EPS from continuing operations is now expected to be in a range of $1.51 to $1.56, slightly higher than our prior guidance due to the adoption of the new accounting standard for stock compensation, worth about $0.08 in the second quarter. 
Before concluding, I'd like to spend a minute to talk about our balanced demand balance capital deployment strategy. We repurchased $400 million of stock in the quarter. As we said on the January call, we expect full year 2016 share buybacks to approximate 2015's levels. We've raised the dividend by 9.3%, our 12th consecutive annual increase. We continue to expect to generate strong free cash flow for the year and target returning 80% to 90% of free cash flow to shareholders, while maintaining strong balance sheet. 
In summary, we saw a good performance in the first quarter. Our bookings were ahead of last year's first quarter and sales, EPS and operating cash flow from continuing operations were all higher than the guidance we set in January. We remain well positioned for the year with our domestic customers priority areas and continue to be aligned with the evolving priorities of our international customers. Our objective is to drive the business to maximize value for our customers and shareholders. With that, Tom and I will now open the call up for questions.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, Toby, you've -- how should I call it. I used to not have a footnote odd items and of late, there has been a couple of adjustments in some of the periods and they've been a little bit more adverse than one would have expected out of Raytheon. Tom, wha
componenttext: Tom, Toby, you've -- how should I call it. I used to not have a footnote odd items and of late, there has been a couple of adjustments in some of the periods and they've been a little bit more adverse than one would have expected out of Raytheon. Tom, what are you doing or Toby to sort of eliminate some of these variabilities with respect to operational challenges?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, there were 2 programs, I think you're alluding to that did impact on Q1 results. They do have unique circumstances. One of them was a program essentially complete, and we are having some, I'd call, warranty issues on some shelters from a sup
componenttext: First of all, there were 2 programs, I think you're alluding to that did impact on Q1 results. They do have unique circumstances. One of them was a program essentially complete, and we are having some, I'd call, warranty issues on some shelters from a supplier. We are working through that with the supplier. We did take a charge this quarter due to that. However, we are working with that supplier essentially recover those costs. Very similar to -- if you look at last year at Missiles, we had an issue with the supplier and we recovered that cost from the supply of last year. This is unfortunately, some cases part of the business when a supplier doesn't perform or has issues, we have to take the charge, but then you go back and recover those costs. That's where we are at on that one. The other one was, though a bit of a stranger deal with the customer relative to some changes in scope and defining who is responsible to scope was and also some other issues relative to the structure of the contract, so it was more of a -- to us it's kind of onetime type of an issue. We don't see that as systemic across the business. So I would -- I'm looking at these 2 as one-off. We are disappointment that the fact that they are they even exist, but we don't see them being systemic across the business. I hope that helps.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the other thing, Howard on these 2 I mentioned I'll reiterate, we don't see any significant financial exposure going forward on either one of these 2 programs. We think this captures And I'd also augment a little bit, we do have a lot of programs
componenttext: I think the other thing, Howard on these 2 I mentioned I'll reiterate, we don't see any significant financial exposure going forward on either one of these 2 programs. We think this captures And I'd also augment a little bit, we do have a lot of programs as we talk about historically across our portfolio. We feel very confident in the processes that by which we used to manage those programs and monitor their progress. As we said, unfortunately here there were some circumstances on these 2 that did impact this year in the quarter. And we're going to work try to at least on first one at IDS. As Tom said, get some of the impact that we sustained during the quarter, recover through the supplier.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a lot of sense. And just as a follow up, the R&D is up again and what we're seeing is, I'll call it a change in evolution and the threat. Tom could you address a little bit some of the opportunities that you see incrementally in aero defense, I
componenttext: That makes a lot of sense. And just as a follow up, the R&D is up again and what we're seeing is, I'll call it a change in evolution and the threat. Tom could you address a little bit some of the opportunities that you see incrementally in aero defense, I think again going back to the There is clearly more need for the U.S. to work on some improvements and I know you're positioning Patriot to take advantage of some of that.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think one of the areas, beside the demand of Patriot upgrade to Configuration 3+ on existing systems, there also has been a demand from new fire units from several countries facing significant issues. As I mentioned, I just came -- I actually been in
componenttext: So I think one of the areas, beside the demand of Patriot upgrade to Configuration 3+ on existing systems, there also has been a demand from new fire units from several countries facing significant issues. As I mentioned, I just came -- I actually been in Middle East twice in the -- since the beginning of the year already. Last won was to celebrate our 50th anniversary in Saudi. And I got first hand information from the folks that are using Patriot systems in both over that period of time from both the UAE and from Saudi. I can tell you that the success has been just tremendous relative to them preventing damages due to missiles landing in the cities and villages. So there's a strong, this in the success of the system, which is, I would say kind of unleashing a lot other demand within the region to have the capability. So there's the basic element. What we're seeing beyond that is a demand on the Patriot systems for an advanced radar with 360 capability, and that demand is essentially primary part of demand is coming from international. We also are seeing it from the U.S. Army, that's a road map to add a 360-degree AESA capable system. So we've invested in that technology. I mean, it goes, all the way back to again the work that we have done almost going 15, 20 years ago, but leading up to how we won the AMDR program using the technology, but now it's transitioning into the Patriot system. We're also seeing high demand for, I would call, third offset strategy concepts and in areas obviously hypersonics, undersea, you saw secretary talk about something called about distributed referenced the work that's been done on Tom Hawk and SM-6 relative to ship capability. So we're seeing a quite bit opportunities for either enhancements to our existing systems or new systems that to mature our position to go win those. We are doing activities to support those. Does that answer your question?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Howard, just from a numbers point of view, the increase in the first quarter were about 3.5% of sales. There is, I'll call it just under $60 million in absolute dollars of increase. The data is spit roughly 50-50, half been related to Forcepoint, which be
componenttext: Howard, just from a numbers point of view, the increase in the first quarter were about 3.5% of sales. There is, I'll call it just under $60 million in absolute dollars of increase. The data is spit roughly 50-50, half been related to Forcepoint, which because of the timing of the acquisitions wasn't in the first quarter of last year. And the other half primarily driven by our missiles business for a lot of the reasons Tom just talked about. And as a reminder, for the full year, we're looking at about 3.2% of sales across the business, that's up from last year, but 80%-plus of that increase again is related to Forcepoint and the balance to the spending across the rest of the defense business.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think some of what you saw in the first quarter at missiles was timing within the year, not just from missiles, but for the total company as I mentioned. We do have a ramp through the year, especially in the back half. So we still see missions to your p
componenttext: I think some of what you saw in the first quarter at missiles was timing within the year, not just from missiles, but for the total company as I mentioned. We do have a ramp through the year, especially in the back half. So we still see missions to your point in the high single digits from a growth point of view with the cadence improving through the second half of the year as we ramp up on some of our recent international production and development programs. We feel we still think we had current guidance and really Q1 was more timing than anything else.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Rob, one thing we're seeing a little different this year. At missiles, we're seeing the demand across the entire portfolio of missiles all of our franchises, Paveway, AMRAAM, AIM-9Xs, griffins, and even resurgence on for Patriot. So it's not just like
componenttext: And Rob, one thing we're seeing a little different this year. At missiles, we're seeing the demand across the entire portfolio of missiles all of our franchises, Paveway, AMRAAM, AIM-9Xs, griffins, and even resurgence on for Patriot. So it's not just like -- it's not like it's in  one area, it's across the whole portfolio.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so the legacy of filtering business from the legacy Websense was down in the quarter by about a third, okay. That said, excluding the acquisition of Stonesoft that we had in the first quarter, even taking that into account, Forcepoint sales on a norma
componenttext: And so the legacy of filtering business from the legacy Websense was down in the quarter by about a third, okay. That said, excluding the acquisition of Stonesoft that we had in the first quarter, even taking that into account, Forcepoint sales on a normalized basis did grow 9%. So the TRITON product and the federal business that came over from RCP more than offset the decrease in the legacy web filtering business.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Toby, can you talk as to whether the -- since the margins were unchanged, especially the IDS and MS, were these charges anticipated when you provided the guidance? Or is it something that, I guess, when you are unwinding this joint venture now it
componenttext: I guess, Toby, can you talk as to whether the -- since the margins were unchanged, especially the IDS and MS, were these charges anticipated when you provided the guidance? Or is it something that, I guess, when you are unwinding this joint venture now it looks like the amount at least is higher than the $90 million it was in the 10-K that change, I'm just trying to think about the offset to these unfavorable changes are?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. That's a fair question, Sam. No, we did not consider these in the guidance that we gave, either the one at IDS or the one at Missiles. Just remember the $90 million in the K that you're referring to would be the cost to us to exit the venture, not nec
componenttext: No. That's a fair question, Sam. No, we did not consider these in the guidance that we gave, either the one at IDS or the one at Missiles. Just remember the $90 million in the K that you're referring to would be the cost to us to exit the venture, not necessary the P&L impact, but the cash impact. But as far as how we would expect to see things improving or recovering us, we do expect to see margins get better or expand in Q2 and beyond that into the second half of '16. As I mentioned before, even looking out into '17, we still see opportunity for margin expansion. And again, as a reminder, that's excluding the $125 million to $150 million impact from the business in '16. That said, if you think about Q2 for a minute, we do expect it to be in line with Q1 venue, when adjust Q1 for the impact of the 2 programs that I talked about, that I mentioned about 100 basis points impact. If you look over the last couple of years from a total company point of view, we typically see our higher margins in the back half and even more towards Q4. We still see it playing up the same this year and it was set up that with the initial guidance we gave you before these charges. We also have the gain in Q3 from the venture exit that we talked about. And then, we do expect the improved performance in Q4 as we ramp up on some of our production programs, flow-through the retirement of risk and benefit from the combination of strong volume and driving efficiency. So there is a ramp, Sam. The increase in the gain on the bench accounts for the part of the way that this is offset, combined with -- we are generally speaking driving more efficiencies through the business in the back half of the year. And again, other than those adjustments in the first quarter, not much is really changed relative to the cadences how we see things ramping up to the year.

componenttext: Okay. And then can you talk a little bit about the Mideast then just in terms of the pace of activity, I know you don't have any big binary orders other than the cutter or our customers making decisions at the pace you expect them? Or you are seeing the timing of them stretch out?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the number one is as you know we've been in the Middle East long time and mention on the earlier 50-year celebration in Saudi. So we've been working a lot of these projects for many years already. So there are several that are coming to frui
componenttext: Well, I think the number one is as you know we've been in the Middle East long time and mention on the earlier 50-year celebration in Saudi. So we've been working a lot of these projects for many years already. So there are several that are coming to fruition. You mentioned one, which is the early warning radar in Qatar. And also we have other activities that we're seeing, I will say strength and that is the area of C5ISR across the region and one of the big areas is integrating all of these Missile defense capabilities that nation has and tying them together and providing a common operating projects for those, tying that together with ann air operating center, and then providing an overall jointing operating center for the entire country. So we're seeing it demand for that kind of capability across the region. And then, outside of the radar I mentioned, just a replenishment essentially of factor that have been either used or now kind of the shelf the expiration dates that they need to replenish, and with that just happening. So we're not seeing anything that's the slipping to the right with those elements in the Middle East right now.

componenttext: I wanted to ask another question about missiles. And for, let's say, for the 4 years ended 2015, this was fairly consistently a $6.5 billion business, now we're going to $7 million or maybe a bit higher than that. And I heard what you said about the sustainability demand through '17, and also, the fact that up-tempo is a factor, is a driver of the growth that we're seeing. So it just when you think -- I don't know if it's possible, but when you think about what the been the growth in '16 and maybe some additional growth in '17, if you could sort of and maybe a couple of large buckets quantify what the drivers are in terms of how much is off-tempo versus how much is sort of anti-ship versus in any other category?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's really 3 -- I'll hit 3 kind of big buckets. One is the off-tempo. I would say the other one just is, I actually call it, the third offset strategy-type efforts that we're seeing in terms of enhancing missile capabilities. I think I already
componenttext: I think there's really 3 -- I'll hit 3 kind of big buckets. One is the off-tempo. I would say the other one just is, I actually call it, the third offset strategy-type efforts that we're seeing in terms of enhancing missile capabilities. I think I already talked about, I did talk about the SM6 and Tom Hawk and adding the anti-ship capabilities. And we're also seeing essentially in the Missile defense area our whole SM-3 product lines and the investments they are with the Missile defense. And if you marry those 2 what you're seeing out in the world today, relative to the tempo efforts that are going on in the Middle East, stuff from North Korea relative to Missile defense required for that it ties in and then overall third offset strategy bringing in the improvements and aero missiles across the board, including it looking at hypersonic's. I think those 3 things are driving it. As I mentioned before, we're not seeing just one of the franchises or a couple of the programs increasing in volume and decreasing demand, it's across the whole portfolio. I think that's what different.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Right. And if you -- would you say that in those 3 buckets, are there roughly equal contributors to the overall growth of the business over '16, '17 time frame? Or is it much more weighted towards one or the other.

So things were on track financially both from a growth and a margin point of view. And we've been talking beyond this year that we would expect to see beyond the high single-digit growth rate this year, moving in from the teams with some margin expansion. So all that still remains on track and Tom can add to that as well.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me step back, because we're going on 1-year since we acquired the Websense company, then integrated in within our Raytheon Cyber Products grew, and then with the recent acquisition of Stonesoft created a, I'll call it a commercial cybersecurity pro
componenttext: So let me step back, because we're going on 1-year since we acquired the Websense company, then integrated in within our Raytheon Cyber Products grew, and then with the recent acquisition of Stonesoft created a, I'll call it a commercial cybersecurity products company website about $600 million revenue, which puts it right up there in terms of the largest cybersecurity commercial software companies in the world. And what we're seeing is the demand for those products across the -- essentially across their major areas  product, the Stonesoft, next-generation firewalls and Shoreview product line that came out of RCP. And we're really looking at how do we go to the next level relative to the growth of that business and one of the areas that we see as a big opportunity is in the large enterprises. The Websense company came across with a very, very strong solid foundation and small of the medium and prices. With some of the larger enterprises. We see segment opportunity in expanding into large enterprise area. And Matt significant experience in that area. He has worked all the way back in Symantec, and also at Harbor Networks. And so we needed to bring in an leader with that kind of experience to go drive the expansion in the market segmentation into those 2 groups. That's really the -- he's the right guy to now come in and take the John McCormack did an excellent job for us and integration and making sure we have solid foundation. But we believe now it's time to bring in somebody who can take us into the next markets especially in the larger enterprises.

componenttext: Great. And then, just 2 quick follow-ups for Toby. One on the adjustment in IDS, have you assumed any recovery whatsoever -- partial recovery of those costs? Or with that, all be a reversal and upside? And then if you could remind us what the pension funding requirements stands at for '17 and '18?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the IDS question, we've not assumed any additional recovery at our outlook beyond the charge we took. But I mentioned and Tom mentioned, we are going to work to pursue that from our subcontractors going forward. On the pension requirement, next y
componenttext: Sure. On the IDS question, we've not assumed any additional recovery at our outlook beyond the charge we took. But I mentioned and Tom mentioned, we are going to work to pursue that from our subcontractors going forward. On the pension requirement, next year, this year we're looking at about $165 million, next year it's about $933 million. And as a reminder, that increases due to the fact that the plant comes out of full funding from PPA point of view. We now have to fund the annual service cost. And obviously, given the market performance last year, we would be needing to recover and fund the are amortize over few years in that we had. When you look at beyond in '17 and beyond, I think the best way to think from a net cash perspective, net funding perspective, while it's not as much as this year, right, which is around a positive $1.3 billion, think of at about $700 million based about current assumptions for the year in '17 and beyond as a run rate going forward.

componenttext: Okay. Going back to margins were obviously, moving around, a fair amount at this point. headline: Raytheon Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So David, I think that's a little tough to do to really define normalize given the mix of development production programs and the timing of completions and start to move around and start consistent business by business. What I can maybe give a little bit
componenttext: So David, I think that's a little tough to do to really define normalize given the mix of development production programs and the timing of completions and start to move around and start consistent business by business. What I can maybe give a little bit of color on, I'll just go real quick by the businesses is maybe giving an indication on how we see things playing out through the balance of this year. So we talked about IDS what happened in the quarter with the $36 million impact, but we do see the margin improving up through the year, partly driven by a improvement in business mix, some of our larger international programs moved to the production cycle, and then you mentioned, a minute ago, we do have in the second half and the third quarter, the gain from the exit of the venture, which is $125 million to $150 million, and that's about 210 million to 250 basis points at the IDS level. For IIS, we're expecting totally year, 7 4 to 7 6, that would be roughly in line with 2015 after adjusting for that Q1  What we see happening compared to Q1 there is improved mix going forward within IIS. Some improved productivity is we move through the year and also some improvement coming from expected our fees for IIS from a Mrs. Point of view, we talked about the impact in the first quarter with the $22 million adjustment. But if we look forward with the balance of the year, we still see missiles getting to the 13% to 13.2% range with margin starting to expand in Q2 and in the second half of the year, really driven by mix and the timing in the ramp up of programs and some expected efficiencies that we would see in sales. And SAS, they were down year-over-year in Q1 as we expect really driven by some mix, but they were little bit ahead of our expectation for the quarter. And then, when we think about SAS moving forward, again we're still in the 12.9% to 13.1% range, and we do expect the margin to improve throughout the year driven by more favorable mix and therefore, the timing of some program improvements. At Forcepoint, real quick, margin improved in the quarter because of the addition of Websense of that question last year, still on track for the total year, 11.5% to 12.5% range, really with a little bit more ramp up our expansion in the second half of the year, driven by 2 things: the completion of integration activities related to the Stonesoft acquisition; and also as the sales ramp up in the back half of the year. So overall, we do see the cadence improving in Q2 as well as the second half, primary as we progress through program-wise cycles on some of our more recent awards, and you to the timing of the expected program improvements as well.

componenttext: So there is the potential for it be a recurring, Myles. We have our shares some of them vest -- some of them in Q1 and some of them vest in Q2. And the determination is whether that there would be an impact is driven by where the market price of the stock is on the divest compared to the price at issuance strike price at issuance. So there could be volatility, but it could be negative volatility as well if our stock price could go go down. So we're going to have to assess that on an annual basis based upon the market and what's happening out there. So I wouldn't necessarily jump to the conclusion that the 100 basis point adjustment is the right thing. It would be something we have to look at on an year-over-year basis.
