headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Raytheon Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.  My name is Towanda, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purp
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Raytheon Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.  My name is Towanda, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Todd Ernst, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed, sir.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you,  Towanda. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today on our second quarter conference call. The results that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we'll reference are available on our website at
componenttext:
Thank you,  Towanda. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today on our second quarter conference call. The results that we announced this morning, the audio feed of this call and the slides that we'll reference are available on our website at raytheon.com. Following this morning's call, an archive of both the audio replay and a printable version of the slides will be available in the Investor Relations section of our website.
With me today are Tom Kennedy, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Toby O'Brien, our Chief Financial Officer. We'll start with some brief remarks by Tom and Toby, and then we'll move on to questions.
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I'd like to caution you regarding our forward-looking statements. Any matters discussed today that are not historical facts, particularly comments regarding the company's future plans, objectives and expected performance constitute forward-looking statements. These statements are based on a wide range of assumptions that the company believes are reasonable,  but are subject to a range of uncertainties and risks that are summarized at the end of our earnings release and are discussed in detail in our SEC filings.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Todd. Good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased with Raytheon's strong second quarter performance. Our global growth strategy continues to drive our results, with second quarter revenue up 3%. Our operating performance in the quarter was solid,
componenttext:
Thank you, Todd. Good morning, everyone. I'm very pleased with Raytheon's strong second quarter performance. Our global growth strategy continues to drive our results, with second quarter revenue up 3%. Our operating performance in the quarter was solid, with a strong increase in sequential margins. And cash flow generation in the second quarter was well above our expectations. Given our performance in 2016 to date and how we are seeing the balance of the year playing out, we are raising our EPS and cash flow guidance for the year. Further, based on strong demand that we are seeing from our global customers, we also have raised our outlook for bookings. Toby will walk you through the details in a few minutes.
During the second quarter, I visited a number of country leaders in the Asia Pacific region. And earlier this month, we hosted several hundred customer meetings at the Farnborough Airshow. It was a remarkable level of consistency among these conversations. That is, customers are interested in capabilities to address 2 key missions. One, support global counterterrorism campaigns; and two, maintain deterrence in a charged geopolitical environment. More specifically, we continue to see strong demand for integrated air and missile defense solutions, precision munitions and C5ISR capabilities. This demand has been broad based across the European, MENA and Asia Pacific regions. Further, this year, there has been an added sense of urgency. I can't think of a time when our international pipeline of opportunities was more robust than it is today.
Our international model, which looks at countries as markets is paying off. Let me give you just a few examples. One of our larger international opportunities over the next several months is the Qatar upgraded early warning radar. This radar will significantly improve Qatar's long-range situational awareness capabilities and represents $1 billion opportunity for the company. This follows on the country's previous order for 10 Patriot fire units and an Air Defense Operating Center. We also see further opportunity in country for TP2 radars as part of a FAD system later in 2017 or 2018. This is consistent with how we have been thinking about the progression of opportunities in the country for sometime.
Another large upcoming opportunity for the company is in Patriot, which is also progressing well. Government-to-government negotiations are ongoing, and we've achieved key milestones with Polish Industry on work share, including signing a letter of intent to work at Poland's largest defense contractor, DGC.
We anticipate that this multibillion dollar opportunity will be awarded some time in 2017. We also see additional opportunities in Poland, including short-range air defense systems related to our product line.
Looking at second quarter, our bookings were strong with a book-to-bill ratio of 1.18. Strength in the quarter was driven by the $1 billion Next Generation Jammer booking at the beginning of the quarter, a nearly $500 million upgrade to Kuwait's 6 Patriot fire units, as well as several notable missile bookings for AIM 9X, Paveway and SM-3. You may recall that we also had a strong bookings in the first quarter, which together with our Q2 results, drove our year-to-date book-to-bill ratio of 1.13. The strength in bookings lays the foundation for future growth and bolsters our confidence in our outlook. 
In the second quarter, International represented 31% of total company bookings. I would also point out that with the Kuwait Patriot booking, this is the second consecutive quarter where we have had a significant award form the MENA region. At the end of the second quarter, 42% of our total backlog was from international customers.
Our sales growth in the second quarter was ahead of our expectations. Domestic sales increased slightly, while International increased approximately 8% in the quarter, showing that our global growth strategy remains on track.
Overall, International represented 32% of total sales in the quarter.
As we look at future growth drivers for the company, I would like to take a minute to highlight a couple of our many examples. In the second quarter, we delivered the first air and missile defense radar to the U.S. Navy's Pacific Missile Range facility ahead of schedule. AMDR is the next-generation integrated air and ballistic missile defense radar for the U.S. Navy's DDG 51 Flight 3 destroyers and fills a critical capability gap for the surface fleet. This delivery is the latest in a series of milestones achieved for AMDR as it advances through the engineering and manufacturing development phase, which is now close to 80% complete.
AMDR will soon transition to low rate initial production. It remains on track for initial delivery in 2019.
Another example of a future growth driver for the company is Small Diameter Bomb II, which we continue to test with the U.S. Air Force. Small Diameter Bomb II features a highly advanced tri-mode seeker, which includes infrared imaging, millimeterwave radar and laser guidance to find and attack targets from ranges that can exceed 40 miles. Testing will continue this summer as the program moves through low rate initial production. Small Diameter Bomb II, represents a $4 billion opportunity over the lifetime of this franchise program.
Before closing, I'd like to take a moment to briefly touch on the fiscal year's '17 defense budget. As most of you know, both the House and the Senate have marked up their respective bills, and there are significant differences between them. These differences will need to be reconciled before the budget is finalized. Given this, and the fact that it is an election year, we are anticipating that there will be another continuing resolution, which will probably extend beyond the election in November. This assumption is considered within our financial guidance range.
Overall, I'm very pleased with the team's performance in the second quarter. Simply put, we had outstanding results, a solid growth and strong execution. I want to thank the team for all its efforts, which continue to deliver for our company and global customers.
With that, let me turn it over to Toby.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay thanks, Tom. I have a few opening remarks starting with the second quarter highlights and then we'll move on to questions. During my remarks, I'll be referring to the web slides that we issued earlier this morning. If everyone would please turn to Pa
componenttext:
Okay thanks, Tom. I have a few opening remarks starting with the second quarter highlights and then we'll move on to questions. During my remarks, I'll be referring to the web slides that we issued earlier this morning. If everyone would please turn to Page 3.
We are pleased with the strong performance the team delivered in the second quarter with bookings, sales, EPS and operating cash flow all better than our expectations. We had strong bookings in the second quarter of $7.1 billion, resulting in a book-to-bill ratio of 1.18. Sales were $6 billion in the quarter, up 3%, led by our Space and Airborne Systems and Missiles businesses. Our EPS from continuing operations was $2.38, which I'll give a little more color on in a few minutes. 
We generated strong operating cash flow of $746 million in the second quarter, which was better than our prior guidance, primarily driven by the timing of collections. Second quarter 2016 operating cash flow was higher than last year's second quarter, primarily due to the timing of payments and cash taxes, as well as lower required pension contributions.
During the quarter, the company repurchased 1.6 million shares of common stock for $202 million, bringing the year-to-date share repurchase to 4.8 million shares or $602 million.
I want to spend a minute talking about the recent ThalesRaytheonSystems transaction that was concluded at the end of June. Raytheon and Thales concluded an agreement to transition the stakeholder positions each company held in the TRS joint venture structure, with Raytheon acquiring 100% of the TRS U.S. operations and Thales acquiring 100% of the French operations. As a result of the transaction, Raytheon made a net cash payment to Thales in the amount of $90 million and recorded a tax-free gain of $158 million at IDS or $0.53 per diluted share in our second quarter financial results. It's important to note that we had previously forecast this to occur in the third quarter of this year at about $150 million.
I also want to point out that we're raising the EPS and operating cash flow guidance that we provided in April, reflecting our strong performance to date. I'll discuss guidance further in just a few minutes.
Turning now to Page 4.
Let me start by providing some detail on our second quarter results. Company bookings for the second quarter were $7.1 billion and on a year-to-date basis were $13.3 billion, an increase of approximately $1.3 billion over the same period last year. It's worth noting that on a trailing 4-quarter basis, our book-to-bill ratio was 1.11.
For the quarter, international was 31% of our total company bookings, and on a year-to-date basis, was 29%. For the year, we expect international to be about 35% of total bookings.
As Tom just mentioned, we booked several significant awards in the second quarter, including about $1 billion for the Next Generation Jammer program for the U.S. Navy, $574 million on domestic and foreign training programs in support of Warfighter FOCUS activities, $487 million to provide advanced Patriot air and missile defense capabilities for Kuwait and approximately $300 million a piece on both AIM-9X Sidewinder, short-range air-to-air missiles and Paveway.
Backlog at the end of the second quarter was $35.3 billion, and on a funded basis, was $26.1 billion, both up approximately $800 million compared to last year's second quarter.
If you now move to Page 5. As I mentioned earlier, for the second quarter 2016, sales exceeded the high end of guidance we set in April, primarily due to the timing within the year and better-than-expected performance across several of the businesses. For the second quarter, our international sales were approximately 32% of total sales.
Looking now at sales by business. IDS had second quarter 2016 net sales of $1.4 billion. As expected, the change in net sales for the quarter was primarily driven by the recognition of previously deferred precontract cost on our international Patriot program in the second quarter 2015.
In the second quarter 2016, IIS had net sales of $1.6 billion, up 3% compared with the same quarter last year. The increase was primarily due to our cybersecurity and special mission programs. Missile Systems had second quarter 2016 net sales of $1.7 billion, a 6% increase from the second quarter 2015 was primarily due to the Paveway program.
SAS had net sales of $1.5 billion. The 9% increase versus last year was driven by higher sales on classified programs. And for Forcepoint, the increase was primarily due to the acquisition of Websense, which we completed at the end of May 2015.
Moving ahead to Page 6. Overall, the company continues to perform well. Our operating margin was 15.9% for the total company and 14.8% on a business segment basis.
It's worth noting that the impact of the TRS gain that I discussed earlier was essentially in line with our prior expectation and was worth $158 million or about 250 basis points at the company level for the second quarter of 2016.
So looking now at the business margins. The increase in margin at IDS included the results of the TRS transaction. Without the transaction, the IDS margin in the second quarter would have been 15.5%, reflecting a strong operating performance. 
IIS operating margin was in line with last year's second quarter. Missiles margin was up 170 basis points in the quarter compared with the same period last year, primarily driven by higher net program efficiencies and a favorable change in program mix in the second quarter of 2016. The decrease in margin at SAS in the quarter, compared with the same period last year, was primarily driven by a change in program mix. 
And at Forcepoint, the second quarter 2016 operating margin was higher than last year's comparable quarter, primarily due to the acquisition of Websense. Forcepoint's Q2 margin improved from Q2 2015, and as expected, was impacted by integration and transition costs.
As we've discussed on past calls, we remain focused on margin improvement going forward. We are continuously looking for ways to lower our costs, enhance our competitiveness and improve affordability for our customers.
In the second quarter, one of the key drivers of our margin improvement was the payoff from our investment in factory automation and equipment upgrades, and we also saw productivity gains from increased operating leverage.
Turning now to Page 7.
Second quarter 2016 EPS was $2.38, better than expected, primarily driven by higher sales and productivity as well as from the timing of the TRS transaction, which as mentioned earlier, was previously forecast to occur in the third quarter. As expected, second quarter 2016 also included the tax benefit associated with the new accounting standard for stock compensation, which we previously adopted in the first quarter, worth about $0.10. Of note, second quarter 2015 included a favorable $0.29 noncash tax settlement.
On Page 8, as I mentioned earlier, we are updating the company's financial outlook for 2016 to reflect our improved operating performance to date compared to our prior guidance.
We still expect our full year 2016 net sales to be in the range of between $24 billion and $24.5 billion, up 3% to 5% from 2015. The increase is driven by growth in both our domestic and international business.
We've increased our full year 2016 EPS by $0.20 from our prior guidance, and now expect it to be in the range of $7.13 to $7.33. The increase is driven by our improved performance in the first half of the year, as well as a slight improvement to the effective tax rate and slightly lower interest expense.
Turning to our share repurchase. Through the end of the second quarter, we repurchased 4.8 million shares of common stock for just over $600 million and continue to see our diluted share count in the range of between 296 million and 298 million shares for 2016, a 3% reduction at the midpoint of the range. Also, based on our strong performance to date, we have increased the range for our 2016 operating cash flow guidance by $100 million, and now see it between $2.8 billion and $3.1 billion.
And as you can see on Page 9, we've included guidance by business. We left the sales unchanged from prior outlook.
Looking at margins. We've increased the margin guidance range for the company, and now see operating margin to be in the range of 13.2% to 13.4% for the full year, up 20 basis points from our prior guidance.
At the business segment level, we now see the operating margin in the range of 12.6% to 12.8% for the full year, driven by higher expected operating margin at IDS and SAS.
Before moving on to Page 10, given our year-to-date bookings strength and our expectations for strong back half of the year, we are now raising our full year 2016 bookings outlook to $26 billion, plus or minus $500 million. This $500 million increase to the prior range is driven by strong demand from our global customers.
On Page 10, we have provided guidance on how we currently see our third quarter for sales, earnings and operating cash flow from continuing operations. We still expect third quarter sales to be in the range of just under $6 billion to $6.1 billion, consistent with our prior guidance. EPS from continuing operations is now expected to be in the range of $1.57 to $1.62, lower than our prior guidance due to the timing of the TRS transaction, which we had previously forecast in the third quarter. Some of this impact has been offset by the timing of performance improvements previously expected in the fourth quarter.
Before concluding, as we have discussed on past earnings calls with regard to our capital deployment strategy, we expect to continue to generate strong free cash flow and maintain a solid balance sheet at our current credit rating going forward.
We remain focused on the deploying capital to create value for our shareholders and customers. This includes internal investments to support our growth plans and productivity improvements, as well as returning capital to shareholders through share buybacks and dividends, making small targeted acquisitions that our technology and global growth needs, and from time to time, making discretionary contributions to our pension plans.
In summary, if you stand back and look at the quarter, we had strong performance. Our bookings, sales, EPS and operating cash flow from continuing operations were all higher than expected. Based on this performance and our near-term expectations, we increased our 2016 guidance for EPS, operating margin and operating cash flow.
With that, Tom and I will open up the call for questions.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen & Company.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on good quarter. Given the strength in the quarter really across the board and the good cash flow, how come you cutback on your share repurchase from the first quarter? And how -- what's your thinking going forward regarding cash deploymen
componenttext: Congratulations on good quarter. Given the strength in the quarter really across the board and the good cash flow, how come you cutback on your share repurchase from the first quarter? And how -- what's your thinking going forward regarding cash deployment?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Toby. Let me address that one. So we had planned and we frontloaded the share repurchase based upon the timing of our cash flows, okay? And we always had Q1 in excess of the balance of the year. We're more than halfway through what we had targeted at
componenttext: It's Toby. Let me address that one. So we had planned and we frontloaded the share repurchase based upon the timing of our cash flows, okay? And we always had Q1 in excess of the balance of the year. We're more than halfway through what we had targeted at the beginning of the year. That said, related to the repurchase, we still continue to see value in our stock. At our last call, we indicated a target of 89 -- 80% to 90% of free cash flow going back to shareholders. Right now, we probably see it maybe at the bottom of that range, pending market conditions. And if we continue to see strong movement in the stock, we're not going to chase the stock price. Share repurchase will still continue to be a core part of our capital deployment strategy with the stated goals reducing the diluted share count over time, and that hasn't changed. But we will continue to be disciplined when it comes to the allocation of our capital.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland with Barclays.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick clarification for you, Toby, and a question, Tom. Toby, on the TRS transaction, is there equity income to consider that we'll be missing going forward? I was just unsure of the accounting implications there but wanted to make sure we all got
componenttext: Just a quick clarification for you, Toby, and a question, Tom. Toby, on the TRS transaction, is there equity income to consider that we'll be missing going forward? I was just unsure of the accounting implications there but wanted to make sure we all got it model correctly. And then for Tom, just on the Forcepoint competitive landscape, I noted during the quarter, obviously, the purchase of Bluecoat my Symantec, I wondered if you could talk to what implications that has for that marketplace and how you think about the landscape post that announcement?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I'll address, Carter the TRS one. There are a few moving pieces with the remaining venture going forward that impact both IDS operating income and -- at the Raytheon level net income. But they essentially offset each other and are not significa
componenttext: Yes, sure. I'll address, Carter the TRS one. There are a few moving pieces with the remaining venture going forward that impact both IDS operating income and -- at the Raytheon level net income. But they essentially offset each other and are not significant to our results so we shouldn't see an impact one way or the other going forward.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on the Forcepoint. I mean -- you're absolutely correct, Carter. Commercial cyber is a dynamic and rapidly evolving environment. You did mention competitive landscape, and it's going to continue to shift. Raytheon continues to invest in R&D to ensure t
componenttext: And on the Forcepoint. I mean -- you're absolutely correct, Carter. Commercial cyber is a dynamic and rapidly evolving environment. You did mention competitive landscape, and it's going to continue to shift. Raytheon continues to invest in R&D to ensure that we have the best product and capabilities for our customers and that's where we're getting feedback from our customers on. I would add one thing is that you probably saw that the multiples and valuations for Bluecoat acquisition do reflect the premium value and growth potential that this commercial cyber market currently has. And just a quick status on Forcepoint, we have the integrated Websense in with our Raytheon cyber products group. It's substantially complete. It was a seamless transition to the organization, and now we are working to complete the transition of the Stonesoft acquisition into the overall company and we see considerable upside potential as we move forward based on this business we have put together.

componenttext: Tom, Toby, I was wondering if you could share -- walk us through what you think these bookings that you've been getting here over the last year or so, tell us about the cadence of revenue over the next several years? Is this going to be linear growth? Do you have some visibility on when all of these bookings are going to actually convert into some revenue streams?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, [indiscernible] you know the nature of our business. Majority of these big awards have a about a 3-year or 5-year cycle, in that range. So traditionally, I mean, we'd lighten up the first year. If it's a 3-year, we lighten up the first year a littl
componenttext: Jason, [indiscernible] you know the nature of our business. Majority of these big awards have a about a 3-year or 5-year cycle, in that range. So traditionally, I mean, we'd lighten up the first year. If it's a 3-year, we lighten up the first year a little bit, lighten up the last year and the middle year is the main. But normally, it's about 3-year duration in terms of revenue generation now majority of the booking. IIS does have quick turn, 1-year type turn business, but majority of the business -- majority of these major awards that we brought in are 3- and -- 3 to 5-year type revenue generators.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add. Obviously, we're not giving guidance for '17 but from -- when you convert that, that strong pipeline to a financial perspective, the backlog we had entering the year on the heels of a 1.09 book-to-bill, strong book-to-bill to the fir
componenttext: And I would just add. Obviously, we're not giving guidance for '17 but from -- when you convert that, that strong pipeline to a financial perspective, the backlog we had entering the year on the heels of a 1.09 book-to-bill, strong book-to-bill to the first 6 months, strong fourth quarter trailing book-to-bill, as Tom mentioned in his comment a pipeline that we haven't seen of this magnitude for quite sometime. We expect to continue to grow that top line, taking all that into account into 2017 and drive margin expansion as well.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm interested on the same topic in missiles. In missiles, you had really nice growth in backlogs, margins have been quite good. Can you comment on the -- about what it is in the trends in the U.S. international mix? And do you see the growth trajectory i
componenttext: I'm interested on the same topic in missiles. In missiles, you had really nice growth in backlogs, margins have been quite good. Can you comment on the -- about what it is in the trends in the U.S. international mix? And do you see the growth trajectory in Missiles as a secular one or are we seeing kind of a temporary jump up on things like Paveway that we may not see continue -- continued growth there in the same -- in the same way we have.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me hit that really quite. It breaks into 3 buckets. The first bucket, I actually mentioned and my prior comments was the counterterrorism, and that's driving the sales on the precision weapons across the board at missiles. The other bucket is deterren
componenttext: Let me hit that really quite. It breaks into 3 buckets. The first bucket, I actually mentioned and my prior comments was the counterterrorism, and that's driving the sales on the precision weapons across the board at missiles. The other bucket is deterrence, that's essentially driving the -- a lot of the work relative to our Patriot missiles and our Patriot Systems. And then the last large bucket is, I would call it -- and these were the Third Offset strategy or the future in terms of upgrades to new missiles and capabilities. In the middle bucket, on deterrence, there's a large -- when you saw that in terms of awards on our standard missile product line. But the bottom line is that missile company is getting significant uptick in each of those 3 major areas, and we should see that going on for sustained period of time, at least over the next 5 years.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Doug, I would just a little bit more near term, if I take that off tempo bucket around our consumables and then the rest of the business that the other 2 buckets that Tom described, think of it this way, the growth this year is split roughly half and
componenttext: And Doug, I would just a little bit more near term, if I take that off tempo bucket around our consumables and then the rest of the business that the other 2 buckets that Tom described, think of it this way, the growth this year is split roughly half and half between -- driven by the off tempo in consumables and the other half to the rest of the business. And as Tom said, based upon the demand we're seeing across the board there, we'd expect all aspects of the Missiles business to contribute to growth over the next 12 to 18 months.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about the $500 million increase you had in the bookings. Is that any one program or is that across the board? And I guess, somewhat related, I know there's been an RFI out for the new increment of the next Jammer -- Next Generation Jammer. I'm wondering if winning on the first one positions you well for the next one? Or if its kind of starting over from the drawing board?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me address the $500 million. The $500 million is multiple opportunities for bookings for the rest of the year, so we're just not hanging our hat on one big award to be able to bring that on board. Relative Next Generation Jammer, that program is movin
componenttext: Let me address the $500 million. The $500 million is multiple opportunities for bookings for the rest of the year, so we're just not hanging our hat on one big award to be able to bring that on board. Relative Next Generation Jammer, that program is moving ahead excellently. It's on schedule and we're very happy about the performance of that program. Obviously, our customer, the Navy, is also very happy with the performance. We are working with the Navy in terms of this -- the next, I call it Next Generation Jammer II or another implementation of a Next Generation Jammer and we are well on our track, I believe, to have a solid offering for the Navy on that program.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think just to add to Tom's point about the $500 million increase, Sam. Across multiple programs, as Tom said, a lot of the bookings, the favorable bookings we've seen so far is timing. But within SAS is where we see a lot of those opportunities play
componenttext: And I think just to add to Tom's point about the $500 million increase, Sam. Across multiple programs, as Tom said, a lot of the bookings, the favorable bookings we've seen so far is timing. But within SAS is where we see a lot of those opportunities playing out. They've had a really strong first half of the year between the international classified booking in Q1, DPSS and NexGen Jammer that we mentioned, so across multiple opportunities but the growth would mostly be in the SAS business.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I was wondering, to be if you could kind of give us what the discount rate impact would be on  FAS/CAS if we do the line today like we've heard from other companies?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, George. So at this point it is too soon to predict where we think things will go between now and the end of the year. We will give everyone an updated outlook as we typically do on the third quarter call. That said, let me give you a little bit of in
componenttext: Yes, George. So at this point it is too soon to predict where we think things will go between now and the end of the year. We will give everyone an updated outlook as we typically do on the third quarter call. That said, let me give you a little bit of insight to a few things. Year-to-date, our asset return is about 4.5%. And due to assets moving, any type of actual return will have to be significantly different than expected at year-end in order to have a meaningful impact on 2017  FAS/CAS and/or net cash. That said, assuming all other assumptions remain the same, every 25 basis points change in our discount rate has about an $80 million impact on 2017  FAS/CAS. And net cash will be unchanged because it continues to be based upon a 25-year average discount rate. So a few variables there that you all can use and model. But again, with half the year left to go, a little too early to predict exactly next year may look like. And we'll update you here at the end of October on our third quarter call.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Tom, you talked about the $4 billion opportunity for SDB 2 talk about the program for a minute? And maybe to that extent, which countries have interest, depending on costs and other things like test results. So can you share with us some of the assumptions that are behind maybe the installed base and adoption that got you to that $4 billion number? And would you categorize that as either conservative or aggressive as we sit here or there maybe upside to that and when you'll hit it.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first of all, [indiscernible] it's definitely going on BF 35 that's going to -- all the of 35 both the domestic and international have an opportunity to be able to use that very sophisticated precision weapon. So I think that's the main aircraft. It al
componenttext: So first of all, [indiscernible] it's definitely going on BF 35 that's going to -- all the of 35 both the domestic and international have an opportunity to be able to use that very sophisticated precision weapon. So I think that's the main aircraft. It also goes onto F-15s and F-16s SM-and it's a pretty simple system to integrate on an aircraft. So we'll be working to put that on any aircraft that we're allowed to go put it. But the bottom line is that, that forecast assumes just the F35's, F15's and F-16s the majority at being domestic so we have still significant upside in the majority of that market in the international place.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel with Jefferies.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to talk maybe a little bit about either risk reduction or margin, however, you want to define it. But IDS numbers are pretty good, IIS numbers both had very strong revenues and margins. And maybe you could talk about where you are in terms of
componenttext: I just want to talk maybe a little bit about either risk reduction or margin, however, you want to define it. But IDS numbers are pretty good, IIS numbers both had very strong revenues and margins. And maybe you could talk about where you are in terms of improving some of the risk management and achieving some of the milestones? Because it looks like those were factors in the results. If could be a little program specific, that will be helpful.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take that, and if Tom wants to add any color, he can. I'll start, Howard, with IDS, right? So we've been talking about IDS for a while, but we obviously continue to see opportunities to expand margin further in the second half of the year. We
componenttext: Yes, let me take that, and if Tom wants to add any color, he can. I'll start, Howard, with IDS, right? So we've been talking about IDS for a while, but we obviously continue to see opportunities to expand margin further in the second half of the year. We did raise our margin guidance based upon the results for the first half of the year, up by about 40 basis points. Half of that was because of a little bit higher off gain on the TRS transaction, and the other half was from productivity we are seeing because of the leverage of the volume going to our factory, the investments in factory automation, equipment upgrades, as we mentioned before. And I talked about our third quarter guidance and how it was, from a timing point of view impacted by TRS moving into Q2. But we did offset, that was worth about $0.50. We did offset about $0.12 of that, primarily driven by further opportunities for net program efficiencies to drive more margin. Those are moving in from Q4 to Q3, not just at IDS, but at other businesses. So we feel really good about where we are headed going forward from a margin perspective. We would expect to continue, as we've been saying, both at the company level and specifically at IDS to continue to expand margins going forward beyond '16 into '17 as well. From an IIS perspective on the sales, they had a good quarter. Their sales were up to 3%, driven by cybersecurity and special mission programs. For the second half, we see their sales in line with last year's second half despite having 4 fewer workdays and we still expect growth for the year at IIS in the low single digits.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'll just cap that off, Howard, with the fact that both our handover plant to and IDS and also our 2's on plant [indiscernible] the 2's plant, we tripled production on several of the missiles there without having a significant need to [indiscernible]
componenttext: And I'll just cap that off, Howard, with the fact that both our handover plant to and IDS and also our 2's on plant [indiscernible] the 2's plant, we tripled production on several of the missiles there without having a significant need to [indiscernible] capital expenditures to be able to do that and then also the IDS plant, as I know you've been at before. The parking lot is overflowing, which means it's not just one shift, that's on multiple shifts. So both of those factories are chugging along at a very high capacity rates at obviously strong single in strong support from higher margins moving forward.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Safran with Buckingham Research.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I heard the comments at the outset of the call and international for the quarter. I noticed, you're not giving out and '17 guide. But I want to know if you could talk on maybe expectations or maybe comment directionally on international demand for next ye
componenttext: I heard the comments at the outset of the call and international for the quarter. I noticed, you're not giving out and '17 guide. But I want to know if you could talk on maybe expectations or maybe comment directionally on international demand for next year, given the strong bookings you're seeing. And as a second part, earlier this year, there were concerns about oil prices, Brexit, things like that might do to international demand for defense equipment. Can you maybe comment about those concerns and tell up geographically where you may be seeing changes in demand and for what types of systems?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me hit the on the international side write off the bat year. We had '17, I did mention the Poland Patriot opportunity and we also have the TPT radar opportunity in 2017 also, 2017, 2018. So that's the that's kind of 2 big ones for 2017. There are also
componenttext: Let me hit the on the international side write off the bat year. We had '17, I did mention the Poland Patriot opportunity and we also have the TPT radar opportunity in 2017 also, 2017, 2018. So that's the that's kind of 2 big ones for 2017. There are also significant number of orders for precision munitions that will be coming in, in '17 and some other areas in terms of the missionized aircraft that we believe will be coming in '17 also. So we believe bottom line, a strong pipeline of international awards in the 2017 time frame.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think you mentioned it Brexit, and I'll make more of a general comment rather than specific to your question about international. We don't see any significant impact at all from Brexit. Just to put it in perspective, the British pound is the functio
componenttext: And I think you mentioned it Brexit, and I'll make more of a general comment rather than specific to your question about international. We don't see any significant impact at all from Brexit. Just to put it in perspective, the British pound is the functional currency for only about 2% of our sales, so not a major impact at all to the company and to the business. And I think on the Middle East, we mentioned the order for Kuwait Patriot upgrade for about $0.5 billion here in the quarter. I think Tom also mentioned in one of his prior comments back in Q1, we had another significant order for about $650 million for an international classified customer. And we've been pretty consistent over the last couple of years with our customers, our nations that produce oil. They have a demand for our products because they're looking to protect their citizens and their sovereignty, and we're seeing no change to that sitting here today.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wondered if you could dive a little deeper into what's driving the bookings strength at SAS? It looks like that's a bit actually the strongest book-to-bill in the first half. And I know there's some nice exposures in there between space and Intel and un
componenttext: I wondered if you could dive a little deeper into what's driving the bookings strength at SAS? It looks like that's a bit actually the strongest book-to-bill in the first half. And I know there's some nice exposures in there between space and Intel and unmanned and some other growth areas. But if you could get a little more specific there? And then related, it looks like the guidance for revenue for the segment implies revenue would decline a little bit in the second half despite those very good bookings and the trend you're on in the first half. If you could sort of explain that, that will be helpful.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know I'll split the question here. As we've talked about earlier, we had a major award in the first quarter and that was that SAS for an international product, which set them up for a good year in terms of conversion of that revenue in 2016, 2017 and
componenttext: You know I'll split the question here. As we've talked about earlier, we had a major award in the first quarter and that was that SAS for an international product, which set them up for a good year in terms of conversion of that revenue in 2016, 2017 and 2018. They've also done quite well in the classified domain in terms of new awards and have been converting those new awards into revenue. They also are working and completing upon the Next Generation Jammer EMD program, which is in full swing. I know there are a significant revenue generator for the overall business. And I can tell you, they're operating on all cylinders relative to all the other programs that they have in there. It's a good healthy mix, I would call it new programs coming on board. Programs that I would call it mature stage and then program that are starting to fall off. So they have a very good, I would call it a very healthy mix of programs that should be good revenue generators here for the next 5 years.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as your question on the sales in the back half of the year. So sales are up 9% in the quarter, 8% year-to-date, driven by classified programs at SAS. The second half will be driven by both domestic and international classified programs. Obviously,
componenttext: As far as your question on the sales in the back half of the year. So sales are up 9% in the quarter, 8% year-to-date, driven by classified programs at SAS. The second half will be driven by both domestic and international classified programs. Obviously, they're off to a good start and we see ourselves ending the year closer to the higher end of their sales range. What may be distorting at a little bit here for you is, we give it you in one of the attachments, our workdays are a little different this year where the back half of the year in Q4, in particular, has 4 fewer workdays than we saw in 2015. If you normalize for that, they would be showing some growth in the low single digits in the second half.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of David Strauss with UBS.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on cash. Toby, maybe if you could just touch on the major components, facility contracts and process continues to build, when does that growth slow or level off? And then cash taxes, whether there's been any improvement there in terms of what you
componenttext: Question on cash. Toby, maybe if you could just touch on the major components, facility contracts and process continues to build, when does that growth slow or level off? And then cash taxes, whether there's been any improvement there in terms of what you're looking for and then the potential to maybe smooth the pension cash that you talked about in 2017?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me start with the CIP. You're right, we have seen a buildup in our CIP balance. This increase was in line with what we were expecting. It was primarily driven by our sales growth, along with the timing of program millstones and collections, i
componenttext:
Sure. So let me start with the CIP. You're right, we have seen a buildup in our CIP balance. This increase was in line with what we were expecting. It was primarily driven by our sales growth, along with the timing of program millstones and collections, including the ramp-up on some of the more recent awards that we've had last year and into the early part of this year. It's also important, and I would note, that our expected cadence a similar this year to prior years with a buildup of CIP in the first half and then a decrease in the second half, really driven primarily by the timing of certain milestones in collections. If you look forward to the end of the year, and I think we talked about this back in Q1, we would expect our CIP balance to be up compared to '15 but more in line with what our balance was at the end of Q1 of 2016. And this is aligned with our growth profile, and again, driven by the timing of program milestones. As we move to the back half of '16 and into 2017, we will continue to focus on driving working capital improvements and cash flow generation across the business.
We obviously saw strong cash flow here in the quarter, some of it was timing, David, right? But some of it was permanent improvement for the year, which is why we raised the outlook for the year by a $100 million to the new range of $2.8 billion to $3.1 billion. As far as cash taxes go, I think that was your second question. No change from a total year point of view from what we were previously expecting there. We still think cash taxes that will be paid a little bit over $900 million for the year, the net off refunds a little over $750 million for the year as well. I think your third question was around the cash impact in '17 from the required funding of the pension. So look, as we've said previously there, when we hold all the assumptions constant, we see our CAS increasing going from '16 to '17 as we transition fully to harmonization and then remaining relatively flat beyond that. In '16, the pension cash flow is a bit of an anomaly. It's up from '15. But then again, after '16, the cash flow for pension still expected to be positive but more, as we've said, in a normalized rate, plus or minus $700 million net positive. We do sea improved cash flow in our business as programs continues progress through their life cycles and achieve significant program milestones that will improve the cash position. And our continued focus on working capital, including cycle time and payment term reductions with our customers will also drive some cash flow, which could -- and will offset part of that increase. As a reminder, that increase is really driven by the plants coming out of full funding from a PPA point of view, and again, primarily having to fund the annual service costs. As we always do, kind of last point here, we'll continue to monitor all aspects of the pension and we will consider making it, if it makes economic sense to the company, to the shareholders, we'll consider making discretionary contributions before the year is over that could potentially have a further impact on the cash flow profile in '17 and beyond.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is a follow-up from the line of Robert Spingarn with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question is a follow-up from the line of Robert Spingarn with Credit Suisse.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I missed in the first time but I was on another call. I wanted to ask for clarification or -- on Paul and Tom and then another question. But this still -- this Polish competition is this still for a pull-up system or is it a shorter range smaller
componenttext: I guess, I missed in the first time but I was on another call. I wanted to ask for clarification or -- on Paul and Tom and then another question. But this still -- this Polish competition is this still for a pull-up system or is it a shorter range smaller system?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's an excellent question. it's actually 2 pursuits, or 2 programs that Poland is pursuing. One is a system that the Patriot System satisfies. And you probably have seen in the press, the Ministry of Defense is moving forward with the Poland acquisitio
componenttext: That's an excellent question. it's actually 2 pursuits, or 2 programs that Poland is pursuing. One is a system that the Patriot System satisfies. And you probably have seen in the press, the Ministry of Defense is moving forward with the Poland acquisition. And so its right -- we're working government-to-government and also Raytheon is heavily involved in that procurement. Then there's another program, which is being competed, and it's a shorter range system that ties directly in with the capabilities of our System, the system that protect our nation's capital. It's also a system that we sold to Oman and about 4 other countries outside the United States. So it's -- the 2 we are obviously -- good position on Poland Patriot and we are working to make sure the we're in a good position on the short range system.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joseph DeNardi with.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joseph DeNardi with.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Toby, just on the idea as guidance, it seems like the revenues ramping up in the back half of the year but margins are coming down a little bit, second you just talk about some of the puts and takes there and whether or that -- the exit rate on the revenu
componenttext: Toby, just on the idea as guidance, it seems like the revenues ramping up in the back half of the year but margins are coming down a little bit, second you just talk about some of the puts and takes there and whether or that -- the exit rate on the revenue side is a good way to think about IDS as growth in '17?

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So from a revenue point of view, for the total year, we see IDS sales roughly in line with 2015, which as you said, the cadence improving as we move through Q3 and 4. That's due primarily to the startup of some new awards this year, as well as the co
componenttext: Yes. So from a revenue point of view, for the total year, we see IDS sales roughly in line with 2015, which as you said, the cadence improving as we move through Q3 and 4. That's due primarily to the startup of some new awards this year, as well as the continued ramp-up on some of our international Patriot programs as they move through their normal life cycle. From a margin point of view, as I said earlier, we still see opportunities for margin expansion. We were pleased with the results in the second quarter. The 15.5% margin that IDS delivered, excluding the TRS gain. As I mentioned, part of that was from accelerating net program efficiencies, profit improvements from the back half of the year into the second quarter. We see a little bit more of that in the third quarter. We upped the margin guidance by the 40 basis points, half of which was attributable to operating performance, the other half to the gain and we would continue -- expect to continue to see margin improvement that IDS beyond '16's rate normalized for the TRS gain, we'd expect to see improvement continuing into '17.

headline: Raytheon Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro with Shapiro Research.

componenttext: Let me hit the first one here [indiscernible] will that our approach the competition. We're treating the program is more than just a near thing. Flying the airplane committed about preparing the highlights for the missions success in advanced and we're looking for their ability to deal with multifaceted and increasingly complex battle space. And so we're bringing to the table is our industry-leading capabilities in training and also next-generation mission systems. And we are -- we believe we are well positioned to provide the Air Force a comprehensive solution to their training needs here. Our offering is that a lean you M3 46 configuration and its already training for fifth generation pilots from Israel, Singapore, Italy and Poland. And it is a complete system from the classroom to simulators to the FF it is operational proven. That provides high degrees of confidence in both schedules, costs and performance based on its own proven ability. Our T-100 solution that incorporates also our team's expertise in live virtual constructive training, we're going to have to try the efficiency and enhance affordability. In terms of timing, it is our understanding that the Air Force this plan to release an RFP by the end of this year and to award a contract by the end of next year. So we're working on is very heavily with an important program to Raytheon its also important program to the prerelease and we believe we have the best solution on that.
